text: Nice building, nice staff... But a little over priced, I took my two girls, they are younger 18mths and 3 years. The movie in the start was a bit much for the little ones, great if your older and can fully understand. The atrium is not to large but full of beautiful butterfly's. Kids loved them! But what they found most fun was the aquatic section. Over all OK... I most likely will NOT be back... However Not due to poor quality but mainly due to cost and feel of value are a little out...

Very cool. They let you watch a very interesting 3D movie about monarch butterflies (optional) and see butterflies coming out of cocoons before going in with the actual butterflies.  Theres lots of them very beautiful with different  Shapes and colours!!   On your way out you get to see stingrays & different types of fishes in an almost mini aquarium - also a display of reptiles before the fishes.  Humid inside  Adult tickets are 20$
Cool place, wife loved all the butterflies, 11 year old son really enjoyed the laser maze.  Won't return because of high prices, worth a one time visit though.

I went here on opening weekend (May 25th) with my friend and her two kids.  Prices are okay-$20 for adults, not sure how much she paid for her kids admission.  The 3D movie was awesome and a nice reprieve from the heat.  The cocoon exhibit was ok-kind of a funky smell but with animals/bugs-not like they can help it.  I was a little disappointed with the butterfly atrium as it didn't seem like they had a huge selection of species-we kept seeing the same kinds again and again.  The atrium was extremely humid, so ladies-get prepared for a facial!  The ant farm bee colony, and the 'aquarium' were small and nothing to write home about.  One thing we were super annoyed about was they had on their website that they had a cafe-it's more like a vending machine-pre-wrapped sandwiches and chips-grab lunch before you get here.  Her kids bought avocado sandwiches and it didn't have a speck of avocado in either sandwich-they gave her $ back and said they don't make the sandwiches there.  Bottom line-it's a one time thing, I'd probably not end up going back unless I had kids.
You can Not Sit in the atrium and not feel the magic of all the flutterbys!  They are spectacular and beautiful and wondrous for all ages.
The experience was nice but a tad pricey for admission fee.  It may be better if there were less people it was very cowed. so I guess if you are a large family it would be best to go during the week.

Anxious to see this new addition and knowing it was being marketed as the largest in the US., my family went on the second day it was open.  Admission for 2 adults and 1 child came to $52 and change, which made it more expensive than other local attractions.  Overall, we enjoyed the experience but it was not worth the money, especially when both the Phoenix Zoo and Desert Botanical Garden are a 15 minute drive away, both are cheaper, larger, provide much more to see and do for a longer period of time, and DBG has it's own Spring Butterfly Exhibit.  Our son enjoyed the 3D movie, and throughout our entire visit, was the most educational aspect provided - although it centered around Monarch butterflies and their migration only.  The Chrysalis Lab, which you visit next, was the highlight of the visit.  However, there was absolutely no information provided aside from the paper tags identifying the types of butterflies in each type of cocoon.  Because you visit this area directly after the movie and the entire theater is emptied directly into this room, you really only have the length of the next movie to enjoy yourself before being crowded in upon by the next incoming group.  Due to my family being at the back of our theater, by the time the room cleared out enough to give us a good view of the cocoons, we had about 5 minutes or so and then were swarmed by the next large group of people anxious to get a look and were crowded out.  The atrium itself was alright, but disappointing for what was being boasted about it.  It was hot and humid, as to be expected, and the vegetation has a lot of growing to do before it can even be considered as rainforest-y.  The butterfly guide provided when admission was paid was both lacking quite a few species which were spotted, and listed a handful which weren't identified anywhere.  Aside from the few guides answering questions for children and marking their punch cards (they received a prize at the end for having a completed punch card), there was absolutely no information, signage, etc. provided anywhere...which was disappointing.  The ant colony and bee exhibit were alright, but have potential to be much better.  There were a few native AZ species in a corner that looked like they were thrown in as an afterthought and were out of place.  The fish seemed as an odd addition, and were nothing spectacular.  All very common species of fish found at any chain pet store and in the center of the room was a touch tank with 4 very small stingray laying on the bottom of the pool.  Only one came up on occasion, and the moment it was touched, went straight back down to the bottom.  Not faulting the stingray and wanting to be left alone, but a lot more could be done with that exhibit if they want to make it memorable in any way.  Overall, a once-a-year-if-that sort of place unless you REALLY like butterflies.  It was expensive, and didn't provide enough for more than 1 1/2 to 2 hours of entertainment in its entirety.  Other valley organizations are cheaper, and have a lot more to offer.  I'll wait until the Odyssey Aquarium is built next to it, before ever venturing back over to that area.

Ooooh butterfly wonderland! This was a really fun date for my boyfriend and I, and it was something new we had never experienced before. Butterflies sound so romantic and pretty, right?  WRONG. When they land on you, it is scary. Every time a butterfly got close to us we were both a little "flighty" (hahahahah). We were very worried about stepping on them, too, so we spent a lot of time staring at the ground. We were about half way through the misty butterfly garden when my boyfriend said "OH  MY GOSH. DON'T. MOVE."  There was  a butterfly on my neck. There was a butterfly on my neck! I whimpered while he took a picture, holding my neck in an awkward position to accommodate the little guy. My boyfriend laughed until it finally flew away. He kept making jokes about it UNTIL he looked down and discovered the same butterfly lounging on the side of his shorts. Then he didn't find it so funny. Ha!   Once we got our courage back and made peace with a few butterfly landings, we really enjoyed finding the different types of butterflies and hanging out in the garden. We got some nice butterfly pictures, too. So, yes, this is a great date place for me. Good memories.

What an unusual place to visit! A large atrium type building swarming, literally, with thousands of butterflies. All types, colors and sizes flying everywhere. It's almost creepy! I was afraid that I was going to step on them as they land everywhere. It was an incredible experience and a camera is a must. I don't know about going in the summer, as it was very humid and warm in there in March. I think this is something everyone should experience. Only annoying part: watching people pick them up after being specifically told not to.

I went here with my seven year old daughter on a Sunday afternoon, and we had a great experience.  The short 3d movie that you watch before you go into the atrium was actually really interesting, we both loved it.  After the movie you go into the atrium.  It was pretty awesome, and that's coming from someone who is afraid of every insect, including lady bugs!  If you do not like things flying at your face and landing on you, this is probably not your thing.  They will land on you, especially if you are wearing bright or neon colors!  There is plenty of room to walk around and also some benches throughout for sitting.  They also have an area where you can check out insects, bees and sting rays, which was neat.  All in all we had a great time.  The only reason I'm giving it four stars is because it is a little expensive, $19 for an adult, $10 for a child, which I think is steep.

I went to Butterfly Wonderland opening weekend, and had a fabulous time. It was nice to be educated about these amazing creatures, and be able to see them flying everywhere in the observatory room. I thoroughly enjoyed the 3D movie, and entire experience. This is a great place to take children, and a fun date idea!

First of all, I have to say I'm very glad to see an attraction like this in Scottsdale & we will definitely go again.  I do agree with many other reviewers that the $20 price tag for adults is a little steep.  For a family of four you're looking at around $70.00 for a visit.  However, they do sell a Family Annual Pass for a little over $120 bucks, so that is definitely the better way to go if you plan on going more than once.  I have 2 kids, a 4 year old, and a 7 year old.  The 7 year old loved it, as she adores anything nature related & is fascinated by animals, insects, fish, etc.  The 4 year old....not so much.  He did not like the butterflies literally everywhere inside the atrium & was frightened by them constantly flying near his face & around him. It seemed the children we saw either really,really loved it or didn't at all & were scared of the butterflies. I admit, as an adult it does take some getting used to all of  butterflies constantly swirling around you at any given time, but once you do it's awesome.  My 7 year old couldn't wait to get a picture with butterflies on her, and we did!  The fish tanks, ray petting area, bee & ant exhibits can be done in about 10-15 minutes, so aren't really much to write home about.  The 3D movie is highly recommended & is very fascinating & beautiful to watch.  Both of my children really enjoyed it & had no problem sitting still through the 15 minute length.   Overall, we enjoyed the educational & unique nature of this attraction. You will have to decide for yourself if you and your children would enjoy this, and whether or not they will be scared by lots of things flying around them.

Entering into a world filled with wonder and a myriad of pupa, chrysalis, and cocoons sets the stage for the visitor who walks through the doors of Butterfly Wonderland. Each exhibit engaged young and old alike, beckoning them to stroll through the growing foliage of their indoor arboretum.   Fluttering about are various species of the lovely winged creature-the butterfly. Some are petite while others have a wing span of about 4-6 inches. All butterflies flutter in a whimsical motion to the sounds of soothing, instrumental music playing on the loud speaker.   Humidity mimics the temperatures of a true rain forest experience-laughter ensues from visitors as butterflies surround them, even stopping for a photo opportunity on the finger of a young girl or shoulder of the most rugged gent.  Proceed with caution as smiles will break out everywhere amongst this charming, Valley habitat.

I loved this place! I could spend all day inside the butterfly room if it wasn't so humid. Butterflies are everywhere and will land on you so you can get some awesome pictures. It was nice to just forget about life and look at all the pretty species of butterflies. I'd definitely go back!   I would recommend wearing light clothing because you will get very sweaty because of the humidity.

I enjoyed Butterfly Wonderland. First you watch a fourteen minute video about butterflies which was very interesting, I learned a few things. Then you're released to the exhibits, they had different bugs and a mini aquarium. They also had an area you could touch the sting rays, which I though was pretty cool. The butterfly area was very humid!! I enjoyed seeing all the different colors and types of butterflies.  It's a little pricey. If you have an AAA card use it!! =) Have fun! Also a cute place to go on a date. It's pretty small we were done in about 45 minutes.

My in-laws are here for the weekend and we spent a lovely morning at the Butterfly Wonderland in Scottsdale.  Definitely an attraction for all ages.  When you enter there is a 3-D movie (about 15 minutes long) about the monarch butterfly.  Interesting and entertaining.  The conservatory is small and there were many people there but it is exciting to see all of the butterflies and get to interact with them up-close.
We had a wonderful 2 hours. We were pretty thirsty afterwards - Sorry, $2.50 for a small drink is a little to much. But the 3D movie great

The butterfly portion was okay. The reptiles and small aquarium was so so. I found the staff to be rude especially in the cafe. My kids were starving so I paid the ridiculous price for a small pizza and it was mostly burned. I let them know and the worker didn't say anything when I let her know- just turned around and walked off. A simply acknowledgment of this issue would have sufficed. We won't be coming back nor recommending it to anyone.
Absolutely stunning! My kids loved it! The only downside was the drive to get there but overall a great experience

Admission was a rip at $20 a person- we spent over $150 for our family to go into a large greenhouse and see some butterflies. Not really $150 well spent. If the cost was half that, I'd say go, but you don't get what you pay for here.

Pros:   1. great atrium with thousands of colorful, fluttering butterflies. Different areas. Would be nice if the topography had slightly more variety. Soothing in almost a zen way.  2. Staff here were great - making sure one didn't leave with an errant butterfly on one's back.   3. Besides Butterfly Atrium (far and away the highlight), there are also interesting areas with many well-designed aquariums, a cutaway view of a live beehive, and some manta rays.   Cons:   1. As soon as one enters, a staff member snaps your photo. Later, one can buy copies of this flash photo in various sizes, in a frame, or not. But no mention when photo is taken that it is not for free. Or its purpose. And one is not given a choice. One is just told, "Stand over here for your photo." One feels hoodwinked and then pressured to buy a copy of the photo later. They take one shot - so if someone in your party looks goofy - too bad. This absolutely should not be one's first impression and experience upon entering.  2. Tickets are pricey, but each member of my party received a $5 discount. Great. But nothing about it on their website. Hard to find ticket price info on their website. If we had known about the discount, we would have come sooner. Was the discount because it was summer? The day of the week we attended? The time? There is no clue on their website.  Nothing about a forced photo (that one is pressed to pay for later) on their website as part of the Wonderland experience.  3. Their website is terrible in terms of useful information being easy to find.

Comes down to "bang for your buck".  If this was $10-!5 an adult and half for child, I would say it is about an hours worth of enjoyment.  But at the price they are charging,, look elsewhere.  The zoo give you hours of enjoyment.  This is a one and too-soon done and never again.

Pretty cool place but too pricey.. the kids liked it but not sure it's worth the money.$75 for our family and we were there maybe an hour. Spend a little more and go to the zoo or the safari park. At least you will be there a couple hours.

I am so enamored with this place I am a lifetime member. I live nowhere near it and somehow find myself there every couple of months. The movie is cute and the pupa station interesting, but I breeze by. Because I need pure butterflies.

Very beautiful and educational but priced to high for the average Joe to bring his whole family. It's also too bad that we can't afford to bring the grandkids, a little over 88 dollars to walk in the doors is too steep for us.

This is a great place to bring your kids. Beyond being just a fun day out, I think one can learn quite a lot about the lifecycle of butterflies and moths. Watching them hatch right in front of your eyes is quite interesting. This is followed by a stroll amongst these beautiful insects inside a giant glass lined atrium. With the humidity kicked up, it's a micro tropical rainforest with small waterfalls and a Koi pond.  I would point out that they can do kid's birthday parties. My daughter did her 10th birthday there and had a great time with all her friends.

I like this place very much. It's a bit pricy for not really having much else to do while being there. I am excited for the Odysea to be completed. Overall it's a lovely escape from the usual outings, peacefully  calm like being in a rainforest. I hope they have plans for the future to make the area for the butterflies even larger because it can get pretty cramped with people.

My family and I had an exceptional time here. We went to the butterfly area where butterflies landed on my children. Great photo opportunity.  There were thousands of butterflies.  They have a laser and mirror maze area. These were awesome for my family.  Really neat.  Last we went to the ocean world. The 3-D movie was great. The ocean carousel was surprisingly unique and a must see.  Fish tanks were OK.  The have other pay-to-play experiences such as penguin feeding etc. I recommend the basics.

An interesting place for kids and adults alike! There is a fun, 3-D movie discussing the life of monarch butterflies and a "nursery" to watch butterflies hatch out of their cocoons. My only piece of advice is for the ladies: Don't bother straightening your hair that day- the butterfly exhibit is very humid!  Beautiful butterflies of so many varieties make it well worth the trip.

I had read the reviews before going. Felt a little weary due to the fact that I have a 1 1/2year old who doesnt like to stay still for more than 2mins but it wasnt that bad. The movie was entertaining even for my toddler. I had an idea from the reviews about the size of this place but holy cow its small. We were done within 20 minutes at the most. It was beautiful but yea pretty small. So thats why I rated it 3 stars; too overpriced for a 20 minute walk. We paid about $56 for 1 adult, 1 military, and 1 child ticket (I have another child, my toddler didnt have to pay). Oh and we didnt get to pet any stingrays, they added sharks so they didnt allow anybody to touch which is understandable but such a bummer. Probably wont return but it was nice to see as a one time thing.

This place was okay but nothing to write home about. We didn't have a bad experience but it didn't wow us either. It was a bit  pricey for something that only takes 2 hours. My son was three years old so perhaps he was too young, but we probably won't go back until he is much older.

I went for a school field trip and thought it was going to be super boring!! Boy was I wrong I went with a second grade buddy and we actually had a good time. The movie was interesting and informative. Then we saw the emergence center and it was amazing me a thirteen year old boy was actually interested in watching a butterfly hatch. Then I thought that was amazing until i saw the observatory full of butterflies and some landed on me and my buddy. Then we went to the aquarium which I felt was a little boring compared to sea world or anything like that but was nice. Overall a nice experience
This place is fantstic!  It takes your breath away.  Such a fun place to take the kids and watch their amazement.

Expensive, but delightful exhibit, took the 4 grandkids and was considering buying an annual grandparent pass, but will not return. About half the staff was pleasant, the rest were just plain rude.  After witnessing more than a few unpleasant staff interactions with other people, I finally decided to call it a day for us when we walked into the room with the interactive manta ray display, and witnessed the employee there barking at the people trying to see the manta rays. This employee intimidated the crowd to the degree that everybody gave up trying to participate and left the room. We didn't even want to approach the display. It's a shame because although it's expensive, the 3D movie was informative and fun, the butterflies were magical, and all the facility is really nice and has an upscale feel to it. The place is off the beaten path, so I am assuming the poor quality of staff is the result of not having a large potential employee pool to choose from. We will see if things improve in the future, but as it stands, I will not go back.
This place is amazing. A must see place. I definitely recommend it to all the visitors who come to Scottsdale.

Great place but over priced. They have an informative and fun 3D movie followed by an emerging room. There we watched butterflies emerging from their cocoons. It was fascinating. There were many different species and we watched several breaking out of their cocoons and start drying their wings. That was followed by an interactive experience with real and very beautiful butterflies. The rest of the facility was fair with a couple spiders, an ant display and bee display. The touch tank with a few live stingrays was disappointing because it was so controlled. The employee kept yelling at everyone to have only 2 fingers up to your knuckle in the pool. This made it virtually impossible to even touch a stingray.  It was nice to go to but too pricey. My middle to teenage children enjoyed the facility too but once was enough. We probably wouldn't return for a year or two.
The 3D movie is great  and the butterflies are  amazing! this is a great place to bring out of town guessts or a great place to go if you an hour or 2 of extra time.  I highly recommend it.
This place is great for kids, particularly my two crazy kids who are in awe and wonder with the thousand of butterflies that are here. For adults, it's good too, but not as great as for the kids.

I fully agree with the positive reviews already posted about Butterfly Wonderland.  It's a well-designed and well-executed display of the life cycle and habitats of butterflies, and the atrium was very enjoyable (although it would probably be more tranquil mid-week during the school year).  I've been to a few other, similar facilities in the US and overseas, and I believe it's on a par with any of them.  My only complaint?  It's overpriced at $18.95 per adult and even at $16.95 for discounted admission (senior, military, AAA).

Our Girl Scout troop spent the afternoon here today and we had a blast.  We were able today find discount coupons, so we paid for an adult and child entered free.  If you can find coupons, that's the way to go, because frankly prices are a bit high.  Once in, you go to a 3D movie about the Monarch Butterflies which was amazing.  Lasts about 15 minutes.  I thought I read on another review that the capacity for this theater is about 25, which is incorrect.  The theater holds about 150 or so.  Thought that would be helpful to know that if you plan on coming with a large group, like we did.   Then onto the atrium.  You go to a small room beforehand where someone goes over the rules.  No running, horsing around because you could accidentally kill a butterfly. You must stay on the walk path (no strollers allowed here).  No touching or swatting at the butterflies, and lastly, no picking the plants or flowers.  The atrium is a bit humid and warm, but today was about 85-90 degrees out and it was fine.  Butterflies are everywhere, sometimes landing on you or on the walkway so watch your step!  My daughter was immediately greeted by a large butterfly on her head and me on my arm and back.  they are so beautiful.  we were there about an hour and a half.  it was really awesome. I would definitely go again if I could find discount tickets again.  The kids are on spring break, but even so, on a Friday afternoon, it wasn't overly crowded and parking wasn't an issue at all. The gift shop and cafe are like any other at other amusement parks.  Nothing super special and pricey.    Overall we all really enjoyed ourselves.

We (3 adults) loved our experience at Butterfly Wonderland. It's worth the $20 entry fee, here's why: 1) gave us a break from the AZ heat 2) watched a 3-D movie with great facts about butterflies 3) The Conservatory-so many species of butterflies  and many opportunities for picture-taking. It is a warm and moist environment and there are benches to sit on to rest. 4) the stingrays in the Amazon Aquatic Display are AWESOME. You get to interact with the rays. 5) the staff are friendly and patient.

A great place for kids to learn about the migratory patterns of butterflies and their various life stages.  Its a little pricey, but worth it. If you live nearby I would strongly consider the $125 annual membership for two adults, and two children.  Here's a little tip: the longer you hang out in the atrium/greenhouse the more sweaty you become from the humidity  The more you sweat, the more the butterflies will land on you to drink your sweat (I know, gross lol)  Also a great place to bring a date.

We went as a family today. We were greeted by kind employees who were extremely knowledgeable and we were thankful. Clearly we had no idea how much it cost to ship butterflies there monthly since they die within two weeks and the moths in four days!  Having to constantly pump water to hydrate the beautiful foliage and flowers isn't cheap.  For those who think it is expensive - well educate yourselves as to how much it cost to run that facility!  My truth after educating myself - CHEAP for how our lives were enriched today!!!  :)  We were blessed by the beauty there. Their 14 miniature three-d movie was awesome!  We highly recommend this sanctuary!  :)

We decided to come here for my birthday and it was a blast!! A very fun and informative way to learn and study our fragile winged friends. As another reviewer said this place is more geared for a "mature" audience because the few little kids that were there with us were all horribly fussy and disruptive.  The monarch film was interesting and I finally got my wish to see an atlas moth in person!!(one hatched while I was there). But you definitely get your money's worth in the terrarium. Over 3000 butterflies of many species flutter about indiscriminate in their little paradise.  To anyone reading I ask that you be gentle with them, their lives are short and frail. So no touchy! Otherwise enjoy the beauty of Mother Nature!

We visited while we were in town on vacation, and we LOVED it! It was much better than we thought and a very unique experience. It is a little pricey ($20/person), but will give the whole family and experience they will never forget.   The atrium it self is very large and house way more.butterflies than we were expecting. There are butterflies everywhere. We all had several butterflies land on us (which made for great pictures).  The movie before hand was informative and entertaining. The small attractions, including live stingray petting were also nice additions. Well worth it to visit at least once.

We brought our family to this place to have a good time. We were having a great time enjoying the butterflies ,and just taking pictures we weren't touching them or anything and the lady with the short hair that was working there scolded us that they can't touch our skin...not instructing us ...scolded us like we were children then we started walking around again and she followed us which is odd..and continued to talk rudely to us and we weren't doing anything but taking pictures. We literally felt harassed. Management needs to teach there employees to treat customers kindly. I won't be coming back to this place !!!

We must have picked the best day ever to come visit, small crowd. The 3 D movie fascinated us all, it was beautifully done. The "nursery" was very well done, they have a huge variety of butterflies compared to some others we have seen. The pavilion itself was gorgeous, so many beautiful , active butterflies. The rainforest atmosphere was done perfectly. I had several hitchhikers, so much fun. My grandkids, ages 7 and 2/12 were entertained by all the different colors of butterflies for a good while. It was 107 outside but was very comfortable in the pavilion.  One of my very favorite exhibits was an active bee colony that had access from the outside. Whoever designed this display is a genius.  We did not spend much time in the small aquarium section as it didn't quite fit with the whole theme. I understand they are promoting the new Odysea aquarium slated to open next year, that is why the exhibit is there. So, as to all the negatives on pricing, a place like this cost a fortune to build. They are not going to make it on a 5 or 10.00 admission fee. It is totally worth the money if you appreciate and want to learn about butterflies and their role in nature. I want my grandchildren to grow up appreciating animals, butterflies, and anything in nature more than video games.

I was pleasantly surprised with my experience here. Despite the admission ($19 for adults) I came out appreciating butterflies.  They have you watch a 3D film about the life cycle, and then you get to see parts of the life cycle live-- like an exhibit of TONS chrysalis in a glass case, growing and the butterfly emerging. I know this sounds super cheesy as I write this but it's fascinating!  Also, though it took a solid half hour, I did allow a butterfly to sit on my hand. You literally go into a greenhouse of them and they are everywhere. It's uncomfortable at first for the fidgety like me.  If someone were visiting from out of town, I'd take them here (but offer to pay for their admission).

I LOVE this place! I always suggest it anytime a friend asks what we should do. It's just so peaceful and relaxing. They have it structured very well. Its fun to watch the movie about the butterflies to learn more about them and then see them actually becoming butterflies next door. Kids and adults love it just alike. I went there a few weeks ago and was worried as it was summer but it was just the right temperature.

I'm giving 1 star for the extreme pricing. The facility is so small, not a lot going on, and they simply charge an arm and a leg. For 2 adults and a kid to do the maze and the wonderland it was over $80. We dragged it out for 2 hours, max. It's neat, the butterflies landing on you. And they are beautiful. But it's way too much money. And this year they break ground on an aquarium - I can't imagine what that will add to the price. For reference, I can spend the whole day at Makutu's Island for $10, and believe me, my 6 year old has way more fun there than a 10 minute walk with the butterflies that we drug out into an hour. If you've seen one butterfly you've seen them all. Save your money. It's just not even close to worth it.

The Butterfly Wonderland is SUCH a cute idea. I can't believe someone hadn't already thought of it and opened it. You go in and there is a cute small museum for butterflies and a gift shop, this is followed by a 3D education movie (great for children) on the Monarch and then you go into the "butterfly wonderland" where you walk along   a little path where the butterflies flutter all around you and land on you. You can take pictures and it is def. great for kids. Overall, it is such an adorable place.   However, I gave it four stars because the prices are high for what it is. This may be because it is new and eventually they will come down. Adults are around $18 dollars each while kids are about 1/2 of that.

What a great place!  My wife and I took my mom here when she visited for the holidays, and we had a really enjoyable time.  The short 3D movie was really well done, and when we finished with that, it was really neat seeing all of the new butterflys 'hatching' out of their chrysallis in the next room.  And when we got to the Butterfly pavillion...well heck, who doesn't like it when all the butterflys float all around you and occasionally land on your shirt? Great!

We bought the lifetime family passes.  Kinda wish we hadn't - given the limited experiences of the Butterfly Wonderland, but I'm sure it'll improve over time.  The short movie, ants & bees, and aquariums are all afterthoughts.    The real attraction is the butterfly habitat.  We took our two kids (2 and 4) and they did not want to leave.  If you're a photographer or a nature person - it's the place for you.  For anyone else - avoid the life-time pass... until you go at least once.  Got a family of 4... go by yourself first to see what that price of admission really get you.

This gets three tentative stars.   It's advertised to be the largest indoor butterfly atrium in "the Americas" and I suppose that is true. But the experience overall was extremely underwhelming and I will tell you why.  First, the good. The Butterfly Exhibit in Boston is much smaller than this place. It's actually more like a closet than anything. So the good news is that Scottsdale's exhibit beats Boston's by several factors.  Now, the bad. I went to the Butterfly Exhibit in Xcaret last year and it was FOUR times bigger than Scottsdale's. Butterfly Wonderland measures ten thousand square feet...Xcaret is forty-thousand and is two full levels.   Now back to Butterfly Wonderland: After paying the fee ($$$!) you go down a hallway showing meager butterfly art. Then you're led into the theater, where you see a brief 3-D movie on Monarch Butterflies. Nice movie. It's definitely geared for kids, so it's very streamlined and the language of the movie is oh-so-easy to understand...but the sheer simplicity of the movie means that lots of information gets weeded out. I am an information geek. Cram my cranium with it! I can take it. Even as a child, I could. All that information would entice me to buy books, research, maybe even plant my own butterfly garden so that I can be a part of the action...  So all too soon, the movie ends. And you are led to the Butterfly Atrium. The atrium itself is very nice, and it should be, since it is brand new. Thousands of butterflies abound! In the air, clustered around flowers, gathering upon each other to get at bowls heaped with cut fruit.   Ten thousand feet is ten thousand feet...and all too soon you walk in your little semi-circle and it's over. I walked slowly, took many pictures and some videos, and was still in and out of the "largest atrium of the Americas" in less than 12 minutes.  After leaving the atrium was a tinny ant exhibit, bee exhibit, scorpion exhibit, and then some aquariums filled with fish you can see at the pet store. The lighting was pretty bad. Many signs were permanently hidden in shadows, making them very difficult to impossible to read. As for the fish and other creatures, the tags just showed their names but no other information. Where do they live? Why are they featured? What do they eat? Are they endangered? These are questions that children and adults ask.  So, the next stop was a stingray tank, which you can step up to. Being able to touch these magnificent animals is definitely a highlight. However. At the Wildlife World Zoo, you can purchase some food for a buck or two and actually FEED these graceful creatures.   Then there is the obligatory gift shop...for kids. Not too many items that would interest an adult. And remember, I'm just a big kid at heart...so I know that the chinsy toys offered just didn't cut it for me as a child as well.   The effort that went into this place is tremendous. But it's very small and you can seriously be done with the whole thing in less time than it took to drive here. I know and understand that they have to cater to the mentality of children, but that does not mean you have to dumb yourself down. Challenge children to think! Challenge their geography! Challenge their vocabulary! Teach them to read and write cursive! But I digress.  This is certainly worth a look. And a look is all you will get. You'll get some very nice pics from the Atrium. Other than that, I recommend the Wildlife World Zoo.

Have taken out of town visitors here on several occasions - really unique place if your looking for something different to do.  My visitors have always remarked about how fun and interesting it was.    It's also nice if you don't want to do a bunch of walking and there are plenty of places to sit down once inside the greenhouse area.  Make sure and wear bright red or orange clothing - the butterfly's will land all over you!

I love coming here to photograph the butterflies and flowers. I only gave it 4 stars because the Waking Up With Butterflies event is not very organized. The first time I went (4/30), the older woman running the check-ins at the front desk was not organized. When it was my turn to check in, she invited the guy behind me to do so first because he was a member. Ok, not that big of a deal.  But I came again on 5/21, and invited my mom this time because she enjoys the photography as well. We were waiting in line for quite some time. When it was the girl's turn in front of us, the older woman called up a mom, dad and their son to check in before her! They weren't even in line! They paid with BOTH cash and a credit card, so it took forever. I could tell the girl in front of us was not happy. She gets checked in, so it's our turn. But the older woman decides to let the 3 ladies behind us go instead because they were members! It was extremely rude. My mom and I were getting very impatient with this. Then as we were trying to pay, one of those 3 ladies had a fit because her name was spelled wrong on her tag. Who cares?! It's not like anyone is going to care. So that made us more mad. We FINALLY paid and checked in after about 15 minutes total. After that, we did enjoy our photography in the atrium, but we will not be doing this event again. It's not worth the trouble of letting people cut in line just because they're members. Maybe have 2 lines, one for members and one for non-members, and 2 people checking those lines in. It will move faster and no one will be mad. OR! Just go through the line and everyone can wait their turn like it should be,

Being a nature lover, I always try to visit aquariums, botanical gardens, etc. when I travel, so I was very excited to learn of this new place in the city I live. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. While the butterfly atrium by itself was pretty nice, it is not the "largest" space of butterflies in North America. The butterfly exhibit within the already HUGE Xcaret park in Mexico is about 4 times larger and set within a netted area of the rain forest with waterfalls and tropical plants. Also, the emergence "gallery" was paltry compared to Xcaret's extensive ROOMS of emerging butterflies in all the different stages of development along with the interesting stages of plants used.   The conservatory has just one circular path that takes about 15 minutes. And after the 15 minute film on Monarch butterflies, I can't justify the steep $20 entrance fee. Ant colony? This was basically just several of the kits that they sell in the gift shop opened and displayed under a glass case. Honey Bee extravaganza? That's a bit of an overstatement. Good luck finding any queens as the lighting is so poor, most of the panels are in darkness. And the "Rivers of the Amazon"? These are just large aquariums of exactly the same fish that you can buy at Petsmart, at which I would rather go to for free. The sting ray pool was a let down too, as even at the World Wildlife Zoo, they have a pool with a ton of sting rays that you can even feed. Here, there are just a few babies that good luck if you get to touch one that may venture to go near your fingers (you are only allowed to put your hand in up to your knuckles).  The cafe looked like an afterthought with one of those cheap Target-like menu boards serving about the same level of food: think hot dogs, chips, etc. Whoever designed this place has made some very poor decisions. How about lower the entrance fee, but have a more inviting sit-down cafe with table service and excellent food? Instead, you have this empty cafeteria-like place with tons of bored employees just standing around.  Basically, I was in and out within an hour and left feeling cheated. Even the gift shop was a total letdown. Where are the magnets? Hello! Wind chimes with butterflies? Nope. Move on.
Well worth it. I highly recommend this to anyone who does not bring a screaming child. The butterflies do not take well to the wailing. Sorry.
I've been twice since it opened. I took a 6. And 9 year old. They loved it! The 3D movie is excellent. I would recommend a visit.

Fun but fairly small.  It only took us maybe 2 hours to go through the entire place and at these prices its really not worth it.  The movie was great but you see a lot of it during the preview online on their website.  The chrysalis area was really cool but you have to wait awhile to see anything since everyone gets dumped into that room after the movie.  The bee and ant exhibits are almost non-existant.  The stingray area was also not very good.  The staff person there did not interact with anyone and when you asked a question, he had no idea about the rays.
Absolutely awesome! What a neat experience. So many beautiful butterflies! I've never seen anything like it. Highly recommend it! Whether you have kids or not, you should go!

What a treasure!  This place is a true gem. The butterfly area was incredible. My husband picked up a companion right off the bat and it held on until the employee brushed it off.  Petting a stingray was fun too :)  Understand this is not inexpensive, but you have to understand the cost of maintaining such a gem.

I was a little hesitant about our trip to butterfly wonderland. Personally, I didn't feel like I could justify spending $20 to spend 10 minutes looking at butterflies. I was wrong because it was definitely worth the money. Butterfly wonderland is a place where you could spend hours without even realizing it. When you first get there you have to watch a tiny "documentary" about the life cycle of the monarch butterfly. I read a lot of negative reviews about this part, but I happened to find it very interesting. Then you go into a little room where they have on display the incoming butterflies that are getting ready to leave their little cocoons. Again, very interesting. The most wonderful part though is when you actually enter the wonderland, and I do not use that word lightly. It honestly feels like a magical wonderland. Like I said previously, I was worried about getting there and only spending a few minutes looking around and then leaving, but we were there for a couple hours without even realizing it. The greenery is beautiful, and the butterflies are breath taking. I will most definitely be returning!

Came here with a friend on a Sunday around 4:00 pm. It had a few families and couples but it wasn't crowded. The whole experience was worth it if you've never seen this sort of exhibit, which I never had. However, as others have said, the price point ($18 per person with student discount) is deterring me from making another visit. But it makes for a fun date or a cool place to take an out-of-towner!   I already loved butterflies but this place has made me love and appreciate them even more. I would recommend at least a one time visit!

AMAZING place!! Staff is super friendly and the butterfly garden is a breath taking experience! It is pretty humid in there though, so don't bring a jacket unless you want to carry it around. There is also a variety of butterfly workshops! I personally enjoy the Butterfly Yoga.

This was such an amazing experience. Way better than I thought. The butterflies are magical! And the insects and reptile viewing was so cool. We all loved the 3D movie also. I would definitely recommend this to all ages. It's really cool. Oh and if you've never seen an Atlas Moth, they have 3 of them. The largest moth in the world.

Finally went to check this place out since its been opened. I have always been hesitant going due to the admission and unfortunatly I felt the same leaving, I feel that 18.95 for an adult is way to expensive for what all is there.  I have a 2 yr old son that liked it ( but wasnt over excited like he is at the zoo) but im glad he was free! Other then the green house there is not much there. When I heard about the ant farm and the Bee's I was thinking something awesome and was totally let down when I saw it. the Ant farm was the size of an average aquarium you have at home and the bee's were even worst there ware 3 windows with only 1 where the bees were. The sting rays and the 6-7 aquariums they have there are small (all fresh water) The only good thing about this place is the green house, basically paying 20 bucks to watch butterflies fly around.   The only reason I'm giving this place a 3 rating is because the faciliy is kept very clean and the staff is nice. I could wrap my head around a 12.00 admission but 18+ tax is just crazy.  I LOVE butterflies and wished this place was much bigger. I hope they add onto this place once this whole odysey complex is developed more. I wish I could be so excited about this place but was let down, SORRY.

Butterfly Wonderland made our weekend. I love, love, love this place. There's a butterfly theater where you learn about the lives of butterflies via 3D, there's a very cute gift shop, a cacoon gallery where you can see butterflies taking form and of course; the habitat.  I've been reading some of the other reviews. Yes of course the habitat is hot and humid, these specific breeds of butterflies are found in the rainforest; other conditions would kill them. Still, I'm positive that even people who aren't either A) cold all the time or B) butterfly enthusiasts will love it. I'm actually warm all the time and I fell in love with the place. Butterflies float right by you, sometimes land on your clothes and flutter in bowls of fruit, flowers and on plants. They are beautiful. It's really calming and amazing to see them so close-up.   Two helpful hints for the habitat: A) you aren't supposed to touch the butterflies with your hands, it's not good for them and B) look at the ground when you're walking, some of the butterflies relax down there.  There's also a small aquarium area with fish and you can pet a stingray. You can see bees in their natural habitat, ants and scorpions also. It would be cool if they had a ladybug exhibit too!  Of course, I bought the limited-time-offer lifetime membership, $100 for lifetime access. I know we'll be back many (many) times. I absolutely recommend this place for a date/family outing/engagement proposal/some-much-need alone time... basically anyone should be able to manage an excuse to go here.

Wonderful experience.  The 3d movie at the beginning really sets the stage for going in.  Once in the variety of butterflies was amazing.  Wear bright colors if you want them to land on you.  Great photo opportunities.  There is a small cafeteria if you want to take a break and go back in.

On vacation here from la we had to check this out. It was absolutely worth the money. Bought a combo ticket to the new aquarium next door and had a great day visiting both. Visited on a weekday which made it less crowded. Good displays at both sites.
This was an amazing experience for all ages.  So many butterflies to look at and take pictures.  If you move slowly they will land and go for a ride.

Had a few hours to kill in the Scottsdale area, and was looking for something to do that wasn't associated with golf, food, or shopping. We decided to check out the Butterfly Wonderland based on all the great reviews, and we were very happy we did.   The center is a great tour and educational experience related to butterflies and their migration (the Monarch in particular), and the main conservatory attraction was great fun. Great opportunity to see and interact with so many different butterfly varieties. With all the colors, patterns, and textures, it is a photographer's dream. The kids were all thrilled to be there as well, especially when they were lucky enough to have a butterfly land on them.  Overall a great way to spend a couple of hours and see something unique. I look forward to taking my daughter back when she is old enough to really enjoy it.

Went here for a school field trip with my sons class. They seemed very disorganized and not ready for 5 classes to show up, it took an hour from when we arrived until our group (there were only 2) to get in. We then had to have the kids sit and wait on the floor before going into the 3D short movie. The movie was informative and the kids all enjoyed it. Then we moved to another room where they displayed the crysallides (sp?) and briefed us on the rules for the butterfly garden. The garden was great and the butterflies were attracted to those that wore super fluorescent shirts. A very old man (wearing a Veterans hat) accidentally stepped backward onto a butterfly on the ground crushing it and the employees response was very short and rude. We were then rushed through the indoor area that has spiders and sharks, barely saw any of it but didn't look too amazing, and then our group left. Overall the kids had a great time but as a parent I wouldn't pay for that experience.

My daughter and I came to visit here from California. To be honest, I was expecting more for my money. The experience of having butterflies fly around me and the kids was great. The kids weren't really thrilled with anything, but that. The staffs are friendly and accommodating.

LOVED THIS PLACE!! Great for kids and adults to go and check out. My little toddler loved it and my sister loved the sting ray :D so yes it is quite beautiful and the price is great...I cant remember exactly what I paid. But I do remember thinking wow that's not bad for 3 adults and a toddler.

We had a great time here.  Everyone was incredibly friendly.  The butterflies were amazing.  So many of them and so many varieties.  Made me wish I had a better camera!  The Native American guy doing the stingray petting pool was hilarious as well.    The mirror maze next door is no joke either.  So used to ones at carnivals which aren't ever good, but this one throws you for a loop!

Been here a few times with my toddlers. The place is beautiful and the butterflies are gorgeous. However it is ridiculously expensive. We are happy to pay more for value, however until they add more features and exhibits, I don't know why they don't lower the price because they are going to lose people in the long run. If you do you love butterflies, it is a great place though. Depends if it's worth it to you

We really enjoyed the atrium with the butterflies flying about freely.  And, sometimes they would just sit there so you could look at them up close and land on you especially if you were wearing white.  They are very beautiful. The 3D movie is very informative and illustrates the stages of the butterfly and length of life.   However, it also seems like a strange combination of other exhibits which are small and not particularly informative.  Their website talks about the ants and bees which sounds interesting but there is little to see. I have to give it three stars because at $19.00 for an adult ticket I think it is a bit pricy experience.

Amazing! Highly recommend. Knowledgeable staff & amazing large building houses butterflies. There is also section at end insects. Interesting too. The next day I went to aquarium, which was also first rate.

Expensive, but worth going at least once. It is $20 for adults and $12 or $13 for kids over 2. The snack bar prices are outrageous... $3 for a bottle of water, $5 for a rice krispie treat... but it is all worth it when you step into the butterfly sanctuary. The butterflies are literally everywhere, probably thousands of them in there. They are not shy. One landed on my 3 year Olds arm and stayed there while we walked through the whole exhibit. Very cool experience.

MAGIC!  But I am getting ahead of myself.  I bookmarked prior to a trip to the "The Grand Canyon State."  It seems like an interesting place to visit if the opportunity presented it's self.  Sure enough it did.    We had some time to kill after taking in some Padre BP.  We like butterflies and this seemed like a nice place to kill some time.  Coordinates put into the iPhone and the route was easily negotiated.    Damn!  The parking lot was not full but it was busy.  The ticket line was full and busy.  I quickly reconsidered the idea of making a visit but the draw of Lepidoptera was too great.  The GF and I settled in and I could not wait to experience and educate myself.  The beginning of the journey consists of a 3D movie about the multigenerational journey of a Monarch butterfly family.  The theater is large and the 3D is awesome!  I learned a lot and I was happy to hear the Monarch epicenter is now a World Heritage Site.  After the movie, you are brought into a briefing area where you are told about the do's and do not's of entering the wonderland.  While waiting to enter you can inform yourself about various stages of butterfly development from Pupa to Adult.  When your time arrives to enter, you are instantly transported into the butterfly equivalent of Wonka Land.  There beautiful creatures are flying about in an amazing biosphere.  Humid and warm but not unbearable.  You can loiter about for as long as you like.  Don't touch!  Various breeds will zoom and do all things adult butterfly related as you meander about.  Sure there were lot's of people but everyone seemed seemed respectful.  The overall beauty and tranquility of these beautiful creatures was....dare, I say.......therapeutic.   Remember to WATCH YOUR STEP.  If you want some extra attention...WEAR BRIGHT COLORS!!
Complete waste of time. They force you to watch a 3D movie about butterflies and then wait even longer after that before you are allowed to see the butterflies.

This was a very nice place took my grandkids yesterday March 29, 2017 very educational, butterflies will land on you. We were there for 2 hours but an hour to an hour and half is plenty of time here, I would recommend it at least once

What an incredible place! If you love butterflies, nature and serenity, the Butterfly Wonderland is the place to be! With over 3,000 butterflies, a small reptile and fish museum, a theater and a gift shop and food court, Butterfly Wonderland is a terrific place to learn about and see up close this amazing species of insect.  When you first walk in, you are given the opportunity to watch a 10 minute film or continue straight to the butterfly exhibit. I recommend watching the film to gain a greater appreciation for butterflies and the obstacles they must overcome to survive and continue their species. I certainly learned a lot! For instance, did you know they only eat milkweed?  From there, it's off to the main event - the giant greenhouse that houses a variety of plants and 3,000 butterflies! It really is a fantastic place. There are literally butterflies all around, and many will land on you as you walk around (be careful where you step by the way). As they say in the museum though, "the butterfly chooses you", so you won't want to touch any or pick them up.  After the greenhouse, there's a small section indoors to take a look at some reptiles and fish. It's not the equivalent of a larger zoo, but there are still many animals to see and learn about.  The food court and gift shop here are standard (decent and pricey), but I certainly recommend at least checking out the gift shop on the way out.  Overall, I loved this unique experience and would certainly venture back on a future trip!

Way way overpriced for what you get.  No need to plan for more than a couple hours.  Seeing the Butterfly's is nice but the place is way small.  The 3d movie is interesting and informative. Be sure you come on a sunny day. Whatever you do,  don't miss the outdoor atrium/conservatory area. We almost missed it which would have deemed the trip a total waste.
the 3d movie was excellent,   atrium and has a lot of butterflies for the kids to look at and interact with.

Meh... There were things I liked, and things I didn't. I probably wouldn't go back anytime soon, but my 7 year old said he would (of course he didn't pay the admission fee to get in either).  *The 3D movie was interesting. Some small children were "ewwww"-ing through it. Their parents took them out of the theater. (I think it was the part where the caterpillar emerges from its egg and eats the egg shell.) *After the movie, you are herded into the chrysalis room, where there are 3 viewing windows full of butterfly chrysalises; some were hatching as we stood there. Unfortunately, people were crowding to see and had no patience to wait their turn. *The butterfly enclosure was neat. However, there was not a wide variety of butterflies flitting around. This is where we spent the most time.  Not sure if you are allowed to touch and pick up the butterflies!?! (At the Desert Botanical Gardens, they have a yearly spring butterfly exhibit, and you are not allowed to touch the butterflies; they can land on you, but you cannot pick them up or handle them.) Some parents were allowing their children to do so. There were no signs or volunteers in the room while we were there. *The ant/bee room had no volunteers or signage either.  My son asked what the medium was that the ants lived in. Again there was no one to ask or explain anything. *The aquarium was another disappointment. There are a few aquariums with random fish swimming around. Again, no signs.  There was a volunteer, but she was sitting in a chair stamping the kids sheets as they entered.  When we came into the aquarium, she informed us the "sting rays were being shy."  The 3 tiny sting rays were sitting in the middle of their huge swimming pool. I know my son was really looking forward to touching the sting-rays (he does every year at the phoenix zoo, and loves it), unfortunately, they were not moving from the middle of their pool. Overall, it's a nice facility. If you are a butterfly enthusiast, it's nice to see, but don't expect to see a wide variety of butterflies. It took us about 1 hour and 35 minutes to go through everything.  I could see other families finishing quicker, especially if you have younger children who want to move on to the next thing and have a short attention span.
This place is everything you would expect. Educated you on butterfly's and a shit load of butterfly's. Definitely worth checking out at least one time

This place is magical! Admission is a little pricey, but definitely worth checking out at least once. You first watch a 3-D movie on the life of a butterfly - very interesting information, and the 3D glasses make it fun to watch for children and adults. You then go into the garden where there are about 2,500 butterflies roaming freely in a rainforest environment. We saw a few kids picking up and touching the butterflies which was infuriating and really sad as you are told multiple times to not do this as the oils from your fingers can kill them. Just me venting on the parents not watching the kids :) I believe there are about 40 different species of butterflies in this atrium and they are all as beautiful as each other. You then go back into the main building where you can see ant colonies, spiders, snakes, fish, etc. It probably took us an hour to go through the whole thing. This is apparently the largest butterfly atrium in the US; we are fortunate to have it here locally!

Myself my wife and my 2 daughters (mature8&9) were visiting Arizona from Southern California. We decided to check out Americas largest butterfly exhibit. Price for adults was 20$ and kids were 13$. We found a coupon for 3$ off each ticket online. Go in the morning before lunch or go after lunch to avoid eating there and large crowds. U will not need more than 3 hours here total.   ---We were a little worried that it would be to "babyish" for our girls. But alas it was not!!! We went during the week and if you go on a weekday expect lots of field trips from elementary schools. That did not inhibit our wonderful experience though.   It starts with the amazing and informative 14 minute 3D movie. Which we all thoroughly enjoyed! Then u go into a smaller room where the butterfly's (behind glass) are not only in their cocoons but are coming out of them. U then get to go into the main attraction - the butterfly atrium!!!! A-mazing ! U can spend as much time in the atrium as u want so peaceful, beautiful and relaxing. You see butterfly's from all over the world in every color that u can think of!! My kids faces when a butterfly landed on them was worth the price of admission! You then go into a very small aquarium where u can touch the stingrays:)   ---- ice cream and drinks were WAY overpriced for a place like this. While we did not eat there I wouldn't recommend it food didn't even look that great. Skip the gift shop and snack shop.

Butterfly wonderland is definitely a WONDER LAND. The place is very clean and organized. Their 3D show is OK(not so great) but it is included with your ticket so sit and relax for 14 mins. Each adult ticket is 20$ at the counter but you can buy a $50 gift card in Costco for $37. There is plenty of parking which is also free. Enjoy!!!!!

We got some beautiful pics of our kids with their cousins here. Its a little pricey but its a beautiful facility and unique place to visit. The kids all really enjoyed it and having the butterflies land on them was enjoyed by all and I did get some very unique photographs during our visit. We will definitely return when relatives visit.

This place is AMAZING.  We went here with a group of 4 kids and 6 adults recently, and all of us had an incredible time.  I can't get over this.  It was so much fun for kids AND adults that we've recommended it to anyone who has asked recently for things to do in the Scottsdale area.  The 3D Movie is wonderful.  There is a glass casing where you can see all types of butterflies being born before your very eyes.  Then you go into a room where tons and tons of butterflies are flying all around you, landing on your head, clothes ... it was beautiful.  Plus, there's a bouncy house for the kids.  Not too shabby!  SO FUN!  ENJOY!!!

This was such a fun experience! Highly recommended !It was kind of a magical experience, watching all The butterflies fly around us. Clean, helpful staff and very educational! Wonderful all the way around!

So pretty here!! You start off by going in a 3D movie, which has information on the lives of butterflies. After that, we got to go in an exhibition that has a lot of cocoons where caterpillars are in the process of transforming into butterflies. It was pretty cool. We were able to go inside the actual butterfly area after. There were so many of them! They were all different colors and sizes. You just have to be careful where you step because there are some that are on the ground. The workers warns everyone beforehand not to touch the butterflies with fingers because our oils will make them lose their sense of taste. Luckily some of them landed on my shoulder and head haha. It was such a great experience!

When I went to see the butterflies, I was not in a good mood.  That quickly changed when I entered the Butterfly Wonderland.  When I entered the butterfly room, I felted as if I had walked into a Disney movie feeling like Snow White.  This is a wonderful place.  Yes, the cost is high, but there is a lot that goes into taking care of the butterflies, plant, nectar, humidity sprayers, etc.  All of this beauty in one place is just great.  I also loved the migration movie.  It really puts things in perspective.  I likes the cocoons as well.  There are improvements that can be made, but I will come back next year and see if they are folding the money back into the environment to bring people back with new items.
Oh what a wonderful place...my girlfriend took me here as a surprise...it's a feel good place...can't explain the peaceful atmosphere... definitely recommend this place

My husband and I were just big kids at Butterfly Wonderland! We were here during the Winter Wonderland Extravaganza and they had Christmas decorations up and women dressed up as angels. Beautiful addition to the experience! The 3D movie was very informative and even though they said it was 15 minutes long, it certainly didn't seem like it, which means it was good. Even the kids in the theater paid attention which is a rare thing to see! Seeing the butterflies hatching was really cool and I'm glad we got to see the moth that almost a foot wide. The atrium was enormous and thankfully wasn't too hot! Many gorgeous butterflies flitting everywhere and the waterfall with koi was a beautiful addition. The pathways are well thought out and they even have birds in residence that eat bugs, yet they don't eat butterflies. The bee/bug/spider/scorpion exhibits are great & the fish are wonderful. The rays LOVED me! We even got a commemorative photo which we rarely do, we're going to scan it to share with family and friends. Definitely a worthwhile experience and we'd love to come back when the OdySea aquarium is finished!

The Butterfly Conservatory is amazing!   You walk the grounds of this huge atrium and there are probably thousands of butterflies frolicking around water fountains and people! That right, people! They fly right up to you, your shoulders, your head, your purse and just..... chill.They also have bee colony, ant colony, scorpions, different species of amazon fish. You can stick your hands in the Touch Tank to pet some rays.  Not just a great place for kids but for adults as well. I can honestly say I was schooled on a few things I did not know about butterflies and moths!

WOW...this place is cool!! Butterflies in the desert, who knew? They start you out with a 3d movie about the flight of the monarch. Very informative and fun to watch, then on to the butterflies...I felt like I was in the amazon. The only downside is it is very warm and muggy inside so dress light. The butterflies like it warm. My kids are still talking about this trip.

I had so much fun!!! Workers were sweet and the butterflies were super cool! I totally got landed on by lots of butterflies. Also, there are coy fish in the butterfly sanctuary. Great for kids and adults.

I have been to Butterfly Wonderland three times this past month.  I'm a grownup with a camera.  Every time I come, the nursery is in different stages of hatch and the butterflies in the garden are different and active.  It is a beautiful place to come and take photos or just look.  I do have one suggestion, it would be nice to have one day where the school children didn't come.  That would give the children with their parents and other adults a bit more room to maneuver.    With that being said, I was there in the mornings each time knowing that there would be busloads of little guys and gals.  It didn't change my mind.  There have been several comments about the prices, It's worth it.
Great experience. Kids loved the place! Wish they had more interactive stuff for kids. It is hard for kids to not touch.

Caution consumers! Specifically this poor review belongs to the Mirror Maze part of Butterfly Wonderland. As annual members of Butterfly Wonderland they sent both me and my girlfriend an email that says this... "As a member of Butterfly Wonderland we are extending a sneak peak at the newest must see in Scottsdale. Just print out this email and you will RECEIVE ONE COMPLIMENTARY WALK-THROUGH PASS."  Seems simple enough but it was at best a bait and switch and more accurately an outright lie.  Adding to the nastiness was a  discourteous staff that found pleasure in being very abrupt about telling us the offer was a mistake which they had no intention of honoring and was good only for a quick single walk through of only their laser area of the venue.  We had two choices.  Pay $9.95 plus tax  per person for each of us and our two children (6 and 4 years old) or we were free to leave. I paid the $43 bucks and we walked through the mirror maze. This Mirror Maze part is not worth the extra fee! My advice is to wait for the carnival to come to town.  The Mirror Maze you'll find in a carnival funhouse will be more entertaining and the carnie staff likely more courteous.

Great place for kids. Nothing like beautiful butterflies of many different colors and sizes landing on you. My 4 year old was in awe! The staff was great and the garden was full of so many different butterflies.

The entry fee for this place is somewhat exorbitant for what you get. I have been to better butterfly conservatories that charge the same $18...one of them in Callaway Gardens in Georgia. Check them out on the internet.   The show starts with an educational 3D movie about the life cycle and migration of Monarch butterflies which was actually quite good. The 3D glasses were functional. I would have felt better if disinfectant wipes were available being a germaphobe. The conservatory is small although packed with butterflies that lacked variety. There are also a few tanks of delicious looking fish that would look better on the grill and a little pool to pet a skate fish or ray. They also had a few tanks of ants and spiders.   The items in the gift shop were not overpriced as the toys in Disneyland and the  quality was above average although they did have those made-in-China plastic pieces of...  Overall a pleasant experience but would not dream of coming back.

I've been here multiple times and it is a must see for anyone who can enjoy the true beauty of nature! They start off with an awesome 3D film where you feel as if you're in the forest with hundreds of butterflies. The actual wonderland with all the butterflies is fascinating! I recommend wearing blues, greens, or red colors as the butterflies are more attracted to them and in turn will land on your clothing!

We took the kids to this and they had a great time. The IMAX movie was great. The kids had fun taking photos of all the different butterflies. We were visiting family in Phoenix, so it was a 30 minute drive. We spent about 2 hours there and the kids also enjoyed petting the manta rays.

I found this place out by a group I belong to. I decided to go ahead instead. I wasn't disappointed. The cost is a bit high. $20 for just me. First they take you into a theatre to watch in 3-D the flight of the monarch butterflies then you go into a small room with large windows showing cocoon butterflies coming out of them. There is such wild metallic gold and silver ones but they were not hatching. Just wish the room was bigger because after the theatre everyone is crabbed into this small room. You have a choice of entering the butterfly exhibit or view the hatching. The minute you go into the live butterfly exhibit they land on you. There is so many different species to take pictures of them.  The area gets really humid and uncomfortable so you leave to the air conditioned cafe or to the ant, bee, aquarium  and stingrays. Amazing large aquariums with someone to tell you about the exhibit. I thought this place was very educational and relaxing even with the large crowd.

This was a really neat one-time experience. If you have kids or if you are fascinated with butterflies, head on over. Lots of road construction on the 101 near here and construction at the site to add on a large aquarium. Tickets are very pricey for what is included( approx. $45 for two adults). Luckily under 3 is free, so we didn't pay for kiddo. We went on a Friday around 11:30 and there were four school buses leaving. Whew!   It starts with a short 3D video about butterfly life cycles and then you can view butterfly cocoons before heading into the conservatory. This part was really cool and our son was amazed by seeing the different colorful species fly right by his face. Bring a camera and dress for hot/humid temps because they fog up this bad boy for the butterflies and plants to thrive. There are also birds and a coy pond. After the conservatory, you can view insects in action and view the small aquarium before exiting through the gift shop.   I don't know that we will be back due to the price but we are glad we went once.

Favorite place I've been since being in AZ. I enjoyed this more than the aquarium in all honesty. There is a cool 3D movie before you get in the conservatory, and a REALLY cool room where they keep the cocoons. You can see some butterflies hatching, and it's amazing seeing all the variations of cocoons. I wish I spent more time in here.   My only complaint was the amount of people in the conservatory. I went on a Thursday at 2pm and I felt like there wasn't enough room to walk with all the kids running around. I would try to go earlier next time.   Can't wait to come back soon!
It was just okay for the price.  The movie was great, the exhibit itself was decent but not for what we paid to get in.  They really should lower the price if they want to attract families.

In A Nutshell:  -Butterfly Wonderland in Scottsdale, AZ is a great place to take anyone who loves nature. -You'll learn and see all about the various stages of a butterfly's life. -You'll also be able to see them first hand and if you wear bright colors you might even have some land on you. -There's also a small aquarium and terrariums w/ reptiles and amphibians.  Overall, it's a very cool place to see and learn about butterflies.

We had a lot of fun exploring the conservatory and fish tanks, but it felt like it fell a little short for what we paid in admission and how long it took for us to see everything. I think we would have liked it to be a little bigger (and maybe a little leas humid) in there. But I do admit, there were plenty of tropical butterflies and a photographer's dream it capture it all.  It seems like the younger children had a more difficult time staying in their seats and staying quiet through the 3D movie, I think mainly because the movie was so calm and quiet. It was a good experience and the kid liked it, but I don't think I'd get a membership just yet because we walked through it fairly quickly. I really wish there was more hands-on, interactive displays or shows about butterflies.

I am from CA and was in the area to go to the mayo clinic for 2 weeks (march 2015) and I absolutely fell in love with this place!  I would go here over and over again.  it was a beautiful and peaceful experience I will never forget.  the staff was wonderful, I wanted to buy everything in the gift shop and the butterflies and garden were fantastic!

Neat place in Arizona where you are able to see butterflies year round. The place is actually smaller than I thought. However, there was tons of butterflies in the exhibit. After seeing the butterflies there is a other places to view such as bees, fish, and ants. This area was not very exciting after seeing butterflies and there was poor lighting. All in all this is a great place to take visitors to experience butterflies. However, don't go on a weekday during in the am. There is tons of school groups making it a little bit crazy... But the experience was still nice.

Things to bring :Camera- Full Phone Charge for pics/video-Wear Yellow/Blue/White Colors AND smell sweet.  My sister and I got there before 10 and received $5.00 off . Which you'll want to use in the Butterfly Cafe.   The 3D movie (included) was excellent quality & informative, then we watched butterflies come out of their cocoons in the nursery. AMAZING. Next we are off into the Butterfly Garden.   Truly magical .... hundreds of butterflies of different species, finches, canaries, tropical foliage, water features, kio, etc.    STAFF & KEEPERS are engaging & knowledgeable. Our day started at 9:30 ended at 3:00.

Had a very nice time. 3D Movie was excellent and the butterfly room was breathtaking as expected. Aquarium was small but nice. Didn't take too long to see everything and was a bit pricey especially if you have a couple of kids in tow. Centrally located which makes it easy to get to and bear lots of other stuff. Don't miss the honey bees.

Extraordinary Magical place! Wear bright colored clothes. I wore a super yellow top and butterflies were landing on my shoulders, chest, hand, arm, back and head! Take your camera. Entrance fee is pricey and they don't take ARRP but they do take AAA for a discount. If you take your younger children...please control them! One of the rules are don't touch the butterflies, don't chase them........I witnessed a couple of brats doing such. If you have a child in a stroller...Watch where you steer!!!! A must see for sure.

I'll be honest.  I'm not a huge butterfly fan.  In general, I'm not a fan of things flying at my face (even pretty things) but my friend wanted to go as part of a birthday outing.    The 3D movie was actually really cool and probably would have been even better had it not been for the children in front of me who were never taught how to behave in public.    The butterfly-ararium (?) was quite nifty as well.  It's similar to the yearly Butterfly House at the Desert Botanical Gardens but on a much larger (and more permanent) scale.  There are LOTS of photo ops here so bring your camera.  Apparently, butterflies like the spa so prepare yourself for a sauna-esque environment.  (My pores were so open afterward!).    There are also other exhibits too...ant farms, bee hives, fish and a sting-ray pool.  Most of the stingrays were anti-social but there was one that seemed to enjoy gliding along the top and making little girls (including me) squeal.  I have no idea how stingrays relate to butterflies but I suppose it's less random than say, giraffes.

I was on a family trip to AZ with my husband and kid to see my cousins. They took us to this plaxe which turned out to be so much fun. As soon as u walk in u u go to this room and watch a short 3D movie about the life of a butterfly.. looooved this movie! So interseting!! then u just walk thru the double doors to the butterfly garden, it was amazing, u could see all kinds and shapes and colors; big and small, thousands of butterflies;pretty cool. The kids were so thrilled. Then we walked out to another room, they had snakes, lizards, frogs and more cool animals in there.. this place is Clean and well taken care of, very friendly staff! It was a nice experience. Totally recommend it!
This place is a great escape in the desert. A garden of beauty for butterflies and guests!

Butterfly Wonderland is amazing ! My son and I really enjoyed ! We have been couple times at this place and would back again ! We had so relaxing time out there ! Butterflies seating on your back , had , shoulders ! Very nice atmosphere and perfect enjoyable temperature inside .

I visited the Butterfly Wonderland on a Sunday and was quite surprised to find it pretty packed, the parking lot had little parking I noticed quite a few people parking along the dirt in the back. My first thought was that they needed a bigger parking lot and more plants,flowers,ect around the building to brighten it up a little. The building itself looks great it has an eye catching shape but the grounds lack a bit of luster, putting a lot of flowers around the outside would help attract the butterflies that are naturally around AZ and would let you begin your 'Experience' even before you walk through the door.   After paying we entered to being our tour, I noticed they had a Mirror and laser maze attached to the building which was a seperate cost but we didn't check out out on this visit.
