The main ticket window sells the tickets for both OdySea and Butterfly Wonderland.   They offer packages for both the Butterfly Wonderland and OdySea. For just the pass to the Butterfly Wonderland, it was $24+tax.  The main entrance was cute, just NOT a "WOW" factor for that price.  Immediately after I went through the ticket gate, they tried to usher me into their 3D theater for a 15 minute show, which is practically mandatory before they allow people to go to see the butterflies, but it was filled with families with children, and that's just not my scene, so I opted out, and went straight into the butterfly room.  The butterfly room is one big room that looks like a mini copy of a tropical forest, obviously filled with butterflies.  The staff gave me some helpful instructions, and was available throughout the exhibit. They also set some fresh fruit out from time to time, which invigorates the butterflies, so they're easier to see. I liked that part a lot. It brought out some butterflies that I wasn't able to see on my own.  The butterfly space is pleasant and pretty. The butterflies are really fun. I had one butterfly sit on me for a half hour. I don't know what makes that awesome, but it really was a good time.  There is a small snack shop which was overpriced and had minimal crap and sodas.  There is a reptile exhibit and tropical fish aquariums that was interesting.  There is also a gift shop with overpriced tchotchkes.  CONCLUSION   I love taking photos, and it's a good place to get a few pictures with some pretty subjects in a nice environment.  I liked the experience, but it's not worth the money to keep coming back.  4/5 RECOMMEND  *Discount packages available.  *Available for group events.  *Plenty of parking out front.  *For more information: butterflywonderland.com

My friend and I have wanted to go to the Butterfly Wonderland for a while and the time came to go! We met up on a Sunday morning and got our ticket to check them out!    What does Butterfly Wonderland got going for them? Well they are the only butterfly atrium in the valley and they say they are America's largest butterfly atrium too. , they say the butterflies inside the conservatory come from butterfly farmers from Costa Rica, Malaysia, Ecuador, Thailand & the Philippines as well as within the US and another fun fact Arizona is home to 344 species of butterflies.  Here comes the sticker shock: its 18.95 plus tax which equals to 20.26 I think it was.    Once you pay your ticket you walk inside and have to wait in a hallway because you will be directed to watch a 14 minute movie on the migration of the Monarch Butterfly in 3D, we had to wait a few minutes because there was a show already playing.  The movie is cool; you follow a year in the life of a few Monarchs.   Once your movie is over you are shown into the conservatory, now this is where the fun is it, so many amazing beautifies fluttering around, some look like they are in a game of tag, some just seeing what everyone else is up to, if you stand still and make small movements you might be blessed to have a few land on you, also was told if you wear bright colors they will be attracted to you too, You are not allowed to hold out your hand or try to touch them, but they are allowed to land on you.  I had a few land on me and also had a few fly too close to my face and gave me a butterfly smack or too! Haha  I could spend hours in the conservatory just watching the butterflies enjoying the sun light.  A few things, the conservatory is a tropical rain forest, its humid and misting water is happening, so dress for the rain forest, leave your bags & purses in the car, no need for all that, watch where you are walking the butterflies land everywhere and just make sure you don't step on them. Also inside the conservatory you will see a Koi fish pond, I thought that was cool but also thought hey don't they eat bugs that might land on the water,aawwee poor butterflies that became fish food .  Once you leave the conservatory you go into a smaller room and check to see if you are smuggling any butterflies, and I know that sounds funny, but there were a few that tried to escape before we went through the door.   Then you get to check a cool ant farm, some fishes and other stuff, and even stick your hand in a tank to touch a sting ray, and yes I did that, but I have fed sting rays before too, it's a cool experience.  This was an enjoyable time, we spent maybe 2 hours enjoying everything, do I feel its worth the 20 buck entry fee, no I don't, but will I be a sucka and do it again yep I will haha.

What a unique experience for couples, family's and individuals to part take in! I have always wanted to check this place out, and my husband secretly planned our anniversary date here. He had purchased the tickets in advance online, which I think was a good idea as we were able to skip the lines and walk right in.   The entryway was very well lit and had a lovely collection of butterfly artwork to look at, which I appreciated while waiting for the first butterfly wonderland experience. Shortly after entering the entrance a host has you enter a theatre room to watch a 3D educational movie that only last 15 mins. The movie itself was quite appealing  After that, they systematically have you leave that room and into another to see many windows full of different moth and butterfly cocoons. Someone is there to answer any questions you have, and we even got the pleasure of seeing 2 butterflies hatch from their cocoons-so cool!!  Next, you are escorted or shuffled into the atrium-groups at a time. Hold your breath, it's that gorgeous!! There were even a couples of string violinist dressed in their tuxes playing to the symphony of the butterflies fluttering about. There are more butterflies to watch, than you can imagine. They land, anywhere and we're very sweet to watch.   This is a memory I will forever hold dear to me!

Who doesn't love butterflies . This place was amazing. So many beautiful butterflies. I was impressed with how many this exhibit had. The set up and grounds were so pretty. It is also a very peaceful sanction to be at. You can relax here and take in the beautiful gardens. I was checking this place out for a school field trip. It is very educational for everyone. Plus the gift shop is amazing. I loved the large selection of Eric Carle products. (The very hungry caterpillar) this is a wonderful place to visit in Arizona.

Welcome to a beautiful land of butterflies! Be prepared to relax and watch a 3D movie of a butterfly names in "Dana!" Then into the live room of butterflies. Also, there is an exhibit free of admission into an aquarium room that has a love sting rat you can pet :) we had a tranquil time and loved it!

Been there twice w/ friends and little kids 2, 4, 6, and 9. We all had a great time and it was just what we needed.   The movie is short at 15 mins which is good since kids = short attention span! 3D made it even better. The small room w/ the glass where new bf's and moths are born- nice palette cleanser between main atractions. The real star is the big room. If a butterfly actually lands on the kids it makes it even more special.   Stingray pool and aquarium were a nice variant, as was gift shop even, I bought them each a little something.  I don't think it's pricey for what you get. Seeing the kids eyes light up - and sharing the experience about something completely outside the normal box of sporting events or video games - to see them enjoy a unique experience w/ nature - was so worth it.

I'll be honest, I had my doubts going into Butterfly Wonderland. It's not that I don't like butterflies, but I don't love them either - I guess I would say I'm indifferent and just never gave them much attention.   I had family visiting and I decided to go because of the raving reviews on Yelp; and quite frankly I am shocked it was as fun as it was!   For starters, they have more than just butterflies - they have some fish, snakes, scorpions and lizards as well. The people here are very passionate about their butterflies, and know a lot of really interesting facts.   The visit starts off with a 3D movie, which turned out to be wonderful - it was a great story and the 3D really adds to the experience.  After you finish the 3D movie, you are then sent through double doors (can't have any butterflies escaping) to a butterfly paradise. The butterfly paradise is full of everything a butterfly could ever want: fruit, beautiful bright flowers, a nice humid and warm environment (but not too hot), water features, etc.   The biggest issue I have is trying to avoid the butterflies! Yes, you actually need to be very careful of your surroundings. As big as humans might be, butterflies do not appear to have any fear of us and do try to land in your foot path. Butterflies also try to and will land on you, I myself had one land on my back during the visit.   Take your time, enjoy the beautiful plants and butterflies and DO bring a camera. Price was certainly reasonable for the enjoyment level.

Hubby and I brought our 15 month old granddaughter here last weekend and had a really good time. You start off watching a movie (with 3-D glasses) that explains the lifecycle of butterflies and then move on to an outdoor atrium where you get to get up close and personal with lots of them. If you are lucky you will even have them land on you like one did on me! Be prepared however as it does get warm and humid in the atrium! Also, strollers are not allowed in the atrium and the area where you park your stroller is very cramped. After the atrium there is a small collection of sea life (fish, eels, rays, etc.), insects (cockroaches, beetles, etc.), and reptiles (snakes, lizards, turtles, etc.) for you to enjoy They do have a snack bar inside  however we did not look at what they offered as we had already eaten. And then of course there is the requisite gift shop upon leaving that has a nice variety of items for both young and old alike. We enjoyed it and so did our granddaughter even though she is only 15 months. We can't wait to take her when she is older!

This is my first time ever going to a butterfly atrium.  This place is definitely a must do for kids (and curious adults) if you're in the area.  They start off with an informative 3D video, then you get to see different types butterflies in their different stages depending on the season you visit.  The atrium was amazing!! In addition they had a few small aquariums, an ant farm, a bee hive and a small pool where you can touch rays

I love this experience. I moved to Az in November 2016. I purchased an annual pass last spring.  I have been 4 times and still enjoy seeing a new variety of butterfly dancing around my head.  I love when they land on me.  I have brought friends and family who were visiting me to enjoy this unique up close and personal encounter.

Came here for Valentine's Day with my boyfriend  Wonderful experience  You must go and see the aquarium exhibit too  Amazing place tons of food and shopping on site  Can't wait to swim with the dolphins next!(;
This place is amazing and is totally worth the ticket fee.  Be sure to check this out!  Get their first thing to avoid overcrowding.

As we proceeded on our Great American Road Trip, we found ourselves in Phoenix visiting friends, but with some time to kill before they got off work. As luck would have it, we found this hidden gem. The entire family enjoyed it, with my daughter doing her "gasp-wow" more than I believe she's ever done before. What I enjoyed most was the chrysalis room where we got to see a luna moth as it emerged from its cocoon. Good stuff.

My 3 year old daughter LOVED this place. She was fully engrossed in the 3D video (about 15 minutes long), adored the butterflies, and had so much fun petting the stingrays. Definitely worth the price of admission, especially on a hot day. The butterfly room is humid, but it's not oppressive. There were probably thousands of butterflies...flying around, on the flowers, on trees, on the ground, and one landed on each of us. Great photo opportunities if you are a photographer. If you have a bug phobia, this is not the place for you, but if you want to get close to butterflies, it's a truly amazing experience.

I wasn't expecting to have so much fun here! I have been to a butterfly exhibit before and it was nothing like this.  Once you pay for your tickets you walk in and take a group picture. There's a wait time to get into the next short movie they show on how the butterflies adapt and evolve. The movie was 3D and very informative. I learned a lot about butterflies and got to see the full process of them develop. We were then led out to the butterflies!   Their home was so big! They were flying everywhere and to see the eggs and beautiful color wings was awesome. They land everywhere so you have to be careful where you walk and how you move. We all ended up having one land on us and we're able to get some pretty cool pictures. My girls loved to see all the different color butterflies and how they eat. The leaves had a lot of the butterflies babies attached to them.   When you're leaving you go through a room where they check to make sure no butterflies were trying to go home with you.  Definitely a must place to visit!

It was PACKED today (spring break) and I felt like they didn't know how to handle the crowd. We waited in line forever to buy tickets, then another line to get tickets scanned and hand stamped, and yet another line to get into the theater. No direction. They should have the lines sectioned off, especially one to bypass the theater and enter the emergence gallery and conservatory faster. I feel this process is really inefficient and slow and definitely could be fixed. So that was frustrating.  The 3D movie was awesome. My kids loved it. I loved it actually :)  The emergence area is small and we were packed like sardines in there. But once we got up to the glass, it was cool to see the butterflies emerging from their cocoons.  Next was the conservatory. This is beautiful! It's just so magical having all these colorful butterflies flying all around. It's enchanting. Note - it is really humid in there and my 4 yr old freaked out and I had to take him out for fresh air and water. Keep that in mind with your little ones.  The snack bar/cafe is really expensive. I recommend bringing your own snacks and water.  They have a small section with bugs (we saw honey bees, a scorpion, a tarantula, and ants), and some aquariums and a small sting ray tank in the middle. I wasn't impressed given the cost of admission. The sting rays are tiny and you can barely pet them.  Overall, the crowds made the experience pretty unpleasant, and BW hopefully will work on handling crowds better. In the future I know not to come during high peak (weekends that's a given, but also school breaks).  I think the admission price is too high as well. Not a lot of interactive exhibits and only one movie. I don't think an annual membership is worth it for those reasons (and with 2 kids, I typically spring for the memberships - zoo, science center, children's museum), but I don't think we will be coming back for awhile.

Beautiful place with tons of species that I hadn't seen before.  The educational video was also fascinating.  $20 is a little steep for admission, but I'm sure the operating costs for maintaining 3,000 butterflies and their environment is substantial.  Very zen.

We checked this place out for the first time and I really enjoyed it. I think it's a bit pricey for a 1-2 hour thing, but it was definitely cool and we learned a lot. I heard if you wear a lighter collared shirt you will get more butterflies to land on you. We had dark shirts on so we had no butterflies land on us. But definitely a cool place to go for all ages

In Scottsdale for business but brought the kids so I was looking for something close they could enjoy. My daughter really wanted to see all the pretty butterflies so we decided to come here. Our hotel gave us $3 off coupons so that was good since it's rather pricey for what you get and the amount of time you actually spend here. First off while checking in the lady who stamped our hands asked where we were from when I answered Southern California she said "oh booo!" Followed by an awkward laugh. I was a little perplexed, boo? Uh? You're booing my state? Wtf. Sorry but California is all over AZ in every way IMO but I would never boo someone else's state, especially when they're visiting your business, it was so off-putting I didn't know how to respond. So kept it moving, first you watch a 3D movie which we all enjoyed showing the migration of the monarch butterflies. After that you go into the atrium with all the butterflies and it was awesome, one landed on me and stayed with me the entire time. After about 20min the kids were done and that was it. Afterwards they have a sting ray/ fish area and you can touch the sting rays, that was okay. Over all that first impression really set the tone and it was really quick. I spent less money taking my kids to the children's museum and they spent all day having fun. This experience while unique only lasted about an hour and is overpriced. Wouldn't recommend this to anyone especially Californians.

Visiting this was quite the experience. There are butterfies wherever you look; flying around you, landing all around and even on you. And so many colors and sizes! Although it's a little pricey I don't regret this visit. I've been to the butterfly exhibit at Botanical Gardens, but this one is far superior. You are "encouraged" to watch a 3D movie prior to entering the atrium, but I wasn't impressed with the movie. But I was totally wowed by the exhibit. If the price was a bit lower I would have given it 5 stars.

5 Stars for the overall experience in the desert, a great idea, we loved it. The Atrium was so awesome, but prepare yourself for a humid tropical setting when you step inside. Literally thousands of butterflies are flying about and I got some great pictures of exotic species.  5 Stars for the 3D movie about the life of a Monarch. Now I really want to visit Mexico where these creatures migrate too for winter. 0 Stars for the waiting area.  5 Stars for the Emergence Gallery and witnessing a couple butterflies being born. We spent a lot of time here, though we went into the Atrium first then came back here due to the overcrowding of the small room.  5 Stars for the selection of food in the Café, the sandwiches were so delicious, we found out that they were from The Vermont Sandwich Company close by. The Banana Bread we devoured. Prices were okay. Try their Vermonter or Phish (tuna) sandwich, great flavour.  0 Stars for the Stingray Exhibit, overheard that they were having problems with keeping them alive.  0 Stars for the Bee and Ant colonies. Had lots of questions but no one to answer them for our group.  0 Stars for the Admission Price. Expensive, but now it's off my bucket list. It was extremely hot outside, standing in the sun, waiting in line. They need to construct some sunshades and outdoor seating.  $18.95 per Adult, $9.95 per Child, $16.95 for Students. They're open from 9-5 daily.

Little more than 20 dollars for an adult. You can get a season pass for about 45. If you have a student ID they'll give you a small discount. There's a 3D movie, the butterfly exhibit, small aquarium, live give display(protected by glass) and a small pool to tough sting rays.   Before the big butterfly area, you arrive earlier in the day you can see some butterflies coming out of their cocoon!!!!

What an amazing place.  At first I was thinking $23 to see butterflies are you kidding me? But after spending a couple hours inside this magical place, it was well worth every penny.  We arrived shortly after they opened at 9 on a cool Friday and started our visit with a short 3D movie that showcases the amazing migration monarch butterflies take each year-really well done.  Next we entered a room where a variety of bitterly cocoons hung that were near to hatching.  We even saw one hatch before our eyes,  Next we entered a large gymnasium-sized room that was warm and humid-an indoor rain forest of sorts- with lots of flowering trees and thousands of brightly colored butterflies of all sizes fluttering around.  We had to watch where we stepped as some were perched on the ground in sunbeams filtering in through the glass-topped roof.  We spent well over an hour watching and taking pictures of so many beautiful species.  Later a 2nd grade field trip showed up which added a bit of frenzy to the peaceful setting but it was still wonderful.  You can stay as long as you wish inside.  When you are ready to leave you enter a small quarantine room to make sure no butterflies are tagging along on your back in an attempted jail break.  There are also some other exhibits with bugs, reptiles and fish, but we skipped those and the gift shop.  A great place to spend an hour or two.  Highly recommended

The experience was the best ......different and they replaced an item taken by TSA and saved my week & the year.......hat off to the front office for taking care a small but sensitive problem ......your the best

Pro:  You get to enter a room where there is a lot of butterfly flying around you. They also allow you to bring your own snacks as long as you eat it at the cafe.   Con:  The place is small. Not a lot to do with admission pricing. If you don't bring your own food either, expect to pay a lot for peanut butter and jelly sandwich.... -___- The room where the butterflies are located also do not have air-condition (only fans) for climate control so it can get hot.
The 3D film was amazing! My 2 year old loved seeing the butterflies flying everywhere (and landing on her). $18.95 is very steep, but I assume this is to offset the opening overhead costs.

Overall really pretty and relaxing. I brought  My 16 month old son. He got bored too fast. He likes to run jump and be wild so it's not really a good place for him. I did feel that it was over priced. You would not spend more than two hour here probably. 2 and under is free tho so I am happy bc he was pretty bored. I feel like it's probably magical for ages between 3 and 10!  Have fun guys!  It's not that humid but they control the temps in there and occasionally spray some mist.  22 for an adult ticket.  So was around 50 for me and my husband to get in.  Also wear bright clothes! The butterflies will land on bright clothes.

This was my Family's first visit to the Butterfly Wonderland. It was amazing. The variety of species of butterflies was abundant. Also there was a rain forest exhibit - Excellent.  We went on a budget and were very surprised at the high cost of everything - food, souvenirs and the pictures you are made to take before entering. We would have loved to taken home the photo as a souvenir - but at $25 for 1 sheet with two photos - we had to reconsider. Take lots of photos if you are on a budget.   Although our experience in the Butterfly Wonderland was FANTASTIC there was still this shadow of expense looming over us for anything we did other that look at the exhibit. It felt like Disneyland with the overpriced food and souvenirs.   The staff was great and well trained and my Grandson was given food pellets to feed the Koi in the pond. That was really nice.  Overall an excellent experience for my Family.   If you are a Family on a budget - be aware of high priced items. Just enjoy the exhibit.

This exhibit was lovely and the people who work there are all REALLY nice and helpful/knowledgeable, but it is really really pricey. Adults are $18 weekdays and it is really a one hour kind of place. The butterflies are beautiful and the movie about the life of a butterfly is informative.

I loved this experience.  It was great for the kids and it was hard to leave.  The butterflies actually land right on you  and there is every kind you can imagine.  So beautiful.  they had to keep it really humid though so its uncomfortable in phoenix heat.  My only complaint is the price! WAY TO PRICEY. but other then that...wonderful

This place is a nightmare. Long lines, hot and sweaty, expensive, and uncomfortable. What better than to take your noisy kids to a indoor sauna full of insects crawling over you. For me this is a nightmare. I give it 2/5 stars because maybe it's just not my thing but I couldn't see many people enjoying this. If you're an athletic type I would recommend top golf nearby or the casino nearby. Not my thing. Horrible experience.

Very neat and interesting butterfly sanctuary!  The price seems a little high but you get to do and see a good amount for $20.   Got to see some butterflies coming out of their cocoons.  Lots of butterflies in the garden, with plenty of them landing on you!    Wear bright colors if you want them to be attracted to you.  Professional staff as well.   The movie at he beginning should be optional though.  Had to wait 10 minutes for the movie to finish so that we could go in and watch it.  It's a good 14 minute movie but it should be optional.

Amazing experience. A must for all families. Great short 3D movie initially. Then you move on to a large room/walking path with thousands of butterflies around you. Where white or bright flower colors. Or even better a white shirt with colored flowers like my wife and they will keep landing on you.

Amazingly beautiful.  You start with a 3D educational film about the life cycle of the butterfly.  It is 14 minutes in length and really is a great hook for the rest of the experience. Then you get to enter the atrium.  Its so green and lush.  Other yelpers warned about the mist but it is equivalent to what you'd get waiting in line at an amusement park, just not cool mist.  It is supposed to mimic the rain forest.    If your little ones are amazed at the THOUGHT of butterflies but are terrified of bugs... this is not the place for them.  My kids loved looking but were not thrilled with the thought of a butterfly actually being able to land on them.  I, however, loved it.  I think you should go through yourself first and gauge how your little ones may respond.    Back the atrium.  So beautiful with spa like, nature sound music playing in the background.  The colors, the photos you can take.  You're so lucky if you can actually SEE a butterfly land on you.  When you leave they actually have a mirror in the exit room for you to see if any butterflies have landed on you.  One was on my back.  The most beautiful black an purple butterfly.  I wasn't quick enough to get a picture.  But since my husband took my sons out, I have no idea how long they were actually in there. Booo...   So I thought after the atrium, the experience was over.   Whoa, not so.   Stingray, ant and Bee hive exhibit.   After that, small aquarium with a sting ray petting tank.   I am always looking for a quick, fun, tactile and highly educational experience for my boys.    This is it.   The price is $19 per adult and $9 per child They do, however, give a Military and AAA discount.

This place is awesome!  We came here on a driving trip vacation from California to Texas.  My wife found that this place was just opened and we specifically decided that we would head to this place.  We were amazed by the butterfly hatchery.  This is the first place that you see when you come here.  They bring in butterfly cocoons from all over the world.  Then you go into the butterfly area.  There are lots of butterflies.  Take a good camera because you will defiantly have a chance to get lots of pictures.  The butterflies fly around and sometimes even land you you.  See some of my pictures.  We really enjoyed it here and we plan on stopping by on our next vacation trip.

The kids love it and that is all that matters!  Tons of Butterflies and right next to OdySea Mirror Maze, which the kids like too.  It looks like they are also building an aquarium here too!  Right off the 101 and easy to get to.

What a wonderful place to spend 2 - 3 hours, exploring at your leisure. Play hookey from work to attend  on a weekday when there are less folks in conservatory.  The 3-D movie was amazing, Monarchs so close you can almost "touch" them! In the Emergence room, it's fun watching the cocoons shaking & the other windows with different phases of metamorphisis. Wear Light colors, and the butterflies in the Conservatory will land & stay with you for minutes at a time.  Don't miss the Bee runway towards the end of the tour- the workers are allowed out of the building to bring fresh nectar back to the "hive" housed inside. The Stingray exhibit is huge, and the Gift Shop  has reasonably priced souveniers. Will be back at least twice a year!

What a beautiful place if you love butterflies! My daughter is a little young for the exhibit (10.5 months and not walking yet) but we still had a great time. The conservatory where they keep all the butterflies is really humid, so I would dress lightly. There's a great 3D movie that teaches you all about butterflies, I hope to be able to watch that one day. If you have little ones, you can't bring your stroller in the conservatory so I'd suggest a baby carries or wrap and make sure to watch where you walk because there are literally butterflies everywhere :)   A very magical and enchanting place for children and adults, reminded me a little bit of Jurassic park! We ended up getting the year combo pass here & the Aquarium to make it more of a day trip because it made sense if you go at least twice.

My fiancé took me on a surprise trip to Butterfly Wonderland today and it was quite a wonderful experience. I had no idea about this new hidden gem in Scottsdale and I will definitely be returning. You start off by going into the butterfly incubation room where you can see butterfly cocoons and butterflies emerging. There was a liaison in the room describing the metamorphosis from caterpillar to butterfly and the different incubation times for different species. It is very interesting to see different types of exotic butterfly cocoons. If you get lucky you can sometimes see one emerging from the cocoon.  We then made our way into the butterfly rainforest area. This room is air sealed so you may have to wait a few moments so that they ensure that no butterflies escape in the transition of the doors opening. This room is very muggy and warm so be prepared for that. It is probably around 90 degrees at least and they keep it that way for the butterflies. At certain times a mist is released and it cools it down substantially but you will get hot in this area. If you are like me the hot, muggy environment will not distract you from the peaceful tranquility of the butterflies and plants. This was such a relaxing experience for me. I spent about an hour in this room and could have stayed even longer. You can refer to your visitor's guide and try to spot different species of butterflies. There are many flying around and so many great photo opportunities. Definitely bring a camera. There is a big water fountain in the middle of the room and it is a little cooler in this area. The butterflies also love this area and it is a very peaceful place to sit and relax. I did not find it to be crowded at all and this was a holiday weekend.  The second area that you are able to view after the butterfly rainforest is an exhibit on ants and bees. It is also quite interesting and it is cool to watch the ants burrow and see how they communicate. The bee hive that they have set up is connected to the desert outside and the bees bring back the honey to a see through bee hive. They have facts posted about how the bees collect honey and how they are good for our environment. The last exhibit is a small fresh water aquarium. It is listed in the brochure as an amazon adventure. This is the area of the attraction that is going through growing pains. I think it will be a really cool exhibit once it has been open for a little longer. I did see a couple of dead fish in the tanks but I know that is common when an aquarium is first opening because the tanks have to balance out. They did not have enough information posted about the fish and we were wondering about the species and the area they were indigenous to. They also have a small sting ray pool with very small sting rays. The liaisons were very good about asking if we wanted to touch the sting rays and while we chose not to, many of the little kids were so happy to be able to have that experience.   Overall I had a wonderful time and will definitely be back. This would be a great place to bring kids of any age as well as a great outing for adults. It is very educational and also a peaceful and tranquil environment.

What an amazing time!  My Girlfriend and I spent almost two hours just hanging out and walking around with the Butterflies.   We also enjoyed the 3D movie and small reptile area as all the exhibits were well maintained and you will be surprised at some of the creatures you will see. We were really surprised with this small gem in AZ.  We spent about three hours here and didn't feel rushed.   The food selection in their cafeteria is nothing special but the bathrooms were spotless.  But we didn't come here to eat, we came to hang out with the butterflies!    I suggest eating before coming here and dressing light and bring some bottles of water as the Temperature inside is pretty warm.   Note: Make sure to wear Green as the butterflies will think you are leaves and they will land all over you!

Cool place. But it is VERY expensive for what you get. A 3D movie, life cycle of butterfly, and walking around the atrium filled with butterfly that land on you. My littles loved the butterfly, but 19 bucks an adult and 10 bucks a kid make for a very pricey trip that lasts about an hour/hour and half depending how long you wonder around the atrium. Would go again if it were cheaper or there was more included in that price. 2 star price, 5 star experince.

This place is AWESOME!!  We went in right as it opened, which is the way to go. It's a little pricey at $19.95, but I think it was definitely worth it. You'll have to make several passes around to see the full spectrum of the butterflies they have (which vary seasonally). You need to be patient, too, as the butterflies won't always open their wings when it's slightly overcast. It's an indoor facility, and fairly humid inside, but the sun shines through. The butterflies will land on you if you stand in the sun and wear a white shirt.   Probably the best part about our experience was that one of our family members studies the butterflies in her free time and ended up giving us an expert tour! Bring a camera and use the guide they give you...it's so fun to identify them! The koi are really cool, too. We even saw some baby quails that hatched only the day before! It's a diverse environment, but it is fairly small. So look for the details! The other must-see is the chrysalis display where you can watch butterflies hatch!   This is one of my very favorite things we did on our Phoenix trip, but go early, or it will be too crowded.

Definely enjoyed the new Rainforest Reptile exhibit.  They also have many new items in the cafe if you're considering eating there (the flatbread pizzas were excellent).  I have to say the parking is still a major issue so can't go up to the perfect rating I used to give this place (before the aquarium came).  While it's still my favorite place to go, if you don't get there as soon as they open, you will probably not get a parking spot. I would be willing to pay extra for parking just to know there is one lot for Butterfly Wonderland & only Butterfly Wonderland.  The aquarium traffic is really ruining what used to be a peaceful zen-like visit here.  Still great inside but good luck finding a place to leave your car! The only time there is any parking is first thing in the morning.
A must visit place, especially with kids. Very peaceful, educational & entertaining place. We had a good time

Absolutely spectacular.  The beginning can be hectic since everyone goes in and out the same theater door. And the emergence room can be  busy.  But waiting to enter and exit the atrium is very understandable and very worth it. You can spend countless hours here. The perfect indoor place for short legs.  This is butterfly care and science at its best.  The bees,  ants an aquarium are a great plus to the visit. Heads up - Atrium is warm and humid but beautiful.

Ok, this may not be any fun if you have small children. Our 6 year old did not like the butterflies landing on her and did not want to spend any time in the habitat. She also found the movie a little scary as it had a lot of close ups of the butterfly in the various stages of its life cycle. The movie is in (3) D and really well done.  We bought the combo ticket which included the mirror maze. I would skip this as it is nothing and costs about $9 per person.  The people were friendly and they have a small aquarium area. The place is only one year old and still trying to find its niche. They are adding attractions so it will be a better experience in (6) months.
We had a nice time but i feel it was extremely overpriced!! There's just not that much to do but walk around and look at the butterflies and take pictures. Much too expensive for this!!!

At first I was hesitant to take my daughter. I thought we would be extremely bored looking at butterflies. But when we went I was in aww. Butterflies everywhere. They were flying in between us and landing on us. It was beautiful. We will definitely be going again.

PRICE OF ADMISSIONS: It's 20.00 for adults and 10.00 for kids. Rounded out to be 34.00 with tax. So it was essentially what I expected.  3D MOVIE: The movie was amazing! It's about 15 minutes long and it's in 3D. There's a point in the movie where thousands of butterflies seem to surround you. That was really fun and cool.  BUTTERFLY ROOM: Was awesome. There were so many vibrant colors of butterflies. Took some great pictures. Interesting to see what kind of habitat they thrive in. There should be an age limit to go in thru though. (No kids under 6 years)  There were butterflies on the ground and there were a lot of toddlers dancing around. Made the experience a little stressful.  BEE/STINGRAY/FISH EXHIBIT: Was terrible. In a corner is a stand with a "jenga style" casing of a colony of bees. It was neat to see but again, almost stuffed in a corner. There were two stingrays at the very bottom of a fairly large tank in the middle of the next room but the water was a little blurry so you could just see their shadows. Fish exhibit was eh...  GIFT SHOP: Ridiculously overpriced! T-shirts were 30.00+, book marks 6.00, stuffed animals were 35.00 and up.  OVERALL: I was disappointed. Started off great with the 3D movie and the butterfly conservatory and ended with random setups almost half thought thru and a crazy expensive gift shop.

Awesome place.  Start with a 3D movie Flight of the Monarchs.  Pretty cool visual and information of monarchs migration.  Then the area where crystallize of butterflies was neat to see them coming out of their cocoon.  Then one of the largest conservatory with several species of butterflies n moths, beautiful koi pond.  Its fairly humid but you can go in and out if it gets too warm.  My niece who loves pokemon used the pamphlet we had to find all the butterflies listed she loved it and a fun treasure hunt game for kids.  Highly recommend for families and kids that love butterflies.  There is a cafe which had reasonable prices for ice cream.  A pretty gift shop to find a pretty souvenir.

Such a fun outing to see the 3d movie, the butterflies hatching and then the atrium where they can land on you.  There are some issues.  Make sure you go early if its hot, because the atrium is outside and to cooled, plus they pump it full of mist to make it a humid heat.  We could only stay out there about 10 minutes before the kids felt sick.  The café is very overpriced and does not allow you to even take your drink out of their little area through the last part on the way out.  There are bees, ants and other bugs to look at.  There are 2 stingrays, this is not like at the zoo, it will take you a while to get to actually pet one.   We have a membership and not sure that we will do it again, because it doesn't change.
My kids and I enjoy coming here on a Sunday afternoon. Price is good and they have fun.

Four solid stars.   The 3D movie was the highlight.  The butterfly exhibit was beautiful.  Dress in layers because it's really warm in there.   There are so many butterflies in there.  My 1 year old and 4 year old were terrified of butterflies because they get so close and some land on you.   We didn't last a long time.  But it is very nice for older kids.   The older kids in there were having a nice time.

OK --- I will second, third and fourth the motion that this place is way too expensive.   It will be financially in jeapordy in about 1.5 years after the novelty has worn off,  and then they'll be begging you poor saps in Scottsdale to bail them out financially with a bond effort !!!       Add not only to the expensiveness of the place, how about the poor set up.   No signs that I saw  telling you where to stand for the movie, no signs telling you when the movies begin or end --- and if I missed them, my bad.   If they weren't there, shame on the dope that designed this place.  Atrium sanctuary is the only good part of the entire place, albeit the movie was so-so.    Oh and the ant and beehive display room --- ho-hum???  Behive somewhat OK, as compared to the ant farm, which was lame and should be pulled from their website as even an attraction.   I've seen better ant farms in my cubbards when my wife spilled sugar in the very back of it and ant's from way outside found it !!!   I've seen other comments that the employees were rude.   Not so much rude, just had no zeal to be there really.  Like they could care less about their jobs, which is understandable if they are making minimum wage, but as much as this place charges, they all had better be making six figures !!!!!!!!    And maybe that is their problem, they are overpaid.    My opinion --- if your kids are into butterflies --- go online and order one of those butterfly sanctuary kits, where they mail you the caterpillars, a neat box with windows and all the info you need to help your caterpillars go through the stages of becoming a butterfly.    Worth more money in memories than this place.

I agree with a lot of the other comments but for a family friendly place it was great. The 3-d movie was for my daughters first 3d experience. It was quick and to the point. The butterfly garden was great. It was humid but the misters helped and there were so many amazing butterflies. My daughter loved taking photos and trying to get them to land on her. I wish there would have been more info on the different types of butterflies. When we left the butterfly garden we went in to see the bees and ants which were very small and I wish there was more info on them too. The water tanks were cool but the sting ray pool was not even working either. More info would be great but we will be back again for sure!

$18.95 for adults & 10% off for AAA members...and ps wear bright colored shirts it attracts the butterflies :-)  What a truly beautiful place!!!! A place right out of a fairytale!!! We were in Arizona visiting my mom for the holiday weekend & was searching for interesting things to do while we were here. Have to say there wasnt tooo too much going on in scottsdale but this is the diamond in the rough!!!! To be able to walk amongst thousands of beautiful butterflies just living their lives is such a breathtaking experience!!!   When i first brought the idea of coming here up to the boys they looked at me liked...butterflies?? are you serious?? but the way their faces lit up when we all entered into the atrium/greenhouse & were surrounded by butterflies was PRICELESS!!!! I wasnt too sure if this was a place more geared towards kids or adults too but I swear all the pictures a group of 5 adults took & the looks on all our faces was reason enough for all adults to check this place out. I will say there are ALOT of kids here...When you walk into the facility after buying your tickets you watch a short 3D movie on butterflies...its actually pretty cool...but hard to enjoy it completely with all the screaming & shouting children but once you get into the atrium it calms down a tad...but remember it is a great place for kids to learn as well so prepare yourself for that if your not a huge fan of the little hoodlums haha.  It really is indescribable. They are everywhere...whizzing past your heads...landing on a flower right next to you...feasting on the bowls of fruit they had laid all over the place & in the middle of it all was a great waterfall fountain. IDK why but it took me a little bit to get used to them landing on me..i would get a little scared & fidgidy like how am i so sketchy about such a beautiful creature hahaha so it may take a bit getting used to not flinching when they waft your way. But it is such a perfectly peaceful place & there is no other place like it. The best part of all is the butterflies actually land on you if you stand still!!! I had one chill on my hand long enough to get some pictures with it!! My advice to all is where BRIGHT colored clothing & shirts & that will attract them to land on you. My mom had on a teal shirt and they would land on her every chance they got. Another guy had 2 butterflies mating on his pant leg for the entire time he was there lol. You can stay in the atrium as long as you like just watch your step because some will land on the ground and just relax there lol.    The one & only reason we didnt stay in the atrium forever is because it is SUPERRRRR hot & humid...ladies...if you dont want your hair getting frizzy either wear it up or wear a hat because we all came out sweaty, wet & looking like we walked thru a monsoon.  They also have a few other rooms with a sting ray petting tank & reptile & spider terreriums as well as you get to see hundreds of butterflies in their cryssalis stage of life..we even got to see a few emergeing from their cocoons!!!  This is such a beatiful place & you really learn alot being here & i would recommend EVERYONE check it out. You will really be taken away to a midsummer nights dream!

We came here with our toddler daughter and she loved the experience of having butterflies land on her. The 3D film was a fun intro to the butterfly world. The highlight was really the large room where the butterflies were flying and landing on people. It was pretty crowded  on the day we went but we enjoyed the experience.
Had an absolute blast! Aimed at kids but I'm 24 and still LOVED it! I'm amazed at these beautiful insects!

Took my 2-year old daughter to the newly opened Butterfly Wonderland and we had a lot of fun. Admission is a little high (2 years and younger are Free though but about $20 for adults), but aside from that there's lots to do and the experience was great. There's a natural flow to the "tour" of this wonderland. You start with a 3-D movie on butterflies then proceed to the massive outdoor aviary. There are tens of thousands of butterflies floating / landing / eating / nesting all around you- and may varieties. The aviary is extremely humid to provide an appropriate habitat for the insects so dress accordingly (imagine the worst day in Florida heat). You can easily spend an hour or more in the aviary- snapping pics for Instagram and watching your kids' expressions as they see butterflies all around them. It's large enough that it does not seem crowded and there are employees everywhere to answer your questions.   After the butterfly aviary you can head back inside (A/C yes!) to see the large ant farm and honeybee hive- boys will particularly enjoy this section. There's also a nicely sized aquarium with about 5-6 tanks full of cool fish. There's also a good sized sting ray pool for the kids to "touch and feel" at will.   Your final stop is the cafe and gift shop. It might be worth your time to cool down in the cafe after visiting the aviary - cold bottle of water and juice for the kids. The gift shop is also nice (pricey) and has a little something for everyone. You can collect hole punches from employees throughout your visit on a "kids card" and trade in for a special prize at the end of your visit. The smaller kids will love it.  I would suggest an early morning visit to avoid larger crowds in the aviary. You can swipe your credit card to pay for admission, and bring some cash for the cafe.

Our first visit today and had a wonderful time with our family and grandchildren. Our two and a half year old granddaughter had a blast! The atrium was amazing and we were fortunate as since we went early the crowds were small. We were there for the 3 year birthday party and so enjoyed the extra activities such as face painting.

The 3-D movie and atrium are great. It's over-priced for the time you actually spend there. Taking a family and out of town visitors turns into a $200 trip for maybe 2 hours. I really wish they extended the military discount to police/fire like most places, but they don't which is a little thoughtless on their part.

I was so excited to come here and was so happy to be able to share the experience with my kids. This is such an cool place and so many different things you are able to see and interact with right when you walk in. You start with a really cool 3D movie that's about 15 minutes long and tells you a lot about the butterfly . I couldn't believe how much I didn't know. Next you walk into a room where you get to see a lot of chrysalis hanging and actually get to watch new butterflies coming out of their cocoons. So cool. My kids at this point were even more excited to get into the actual exhibit. After learning some more about the chrysalis we walked into the exhibit. I will tell you they warn you ahead of time how humid it is when you walk in and man they are right. If this is something you think your body can't handle be cautious. It was beautiful! I could not believe how many different butterflies there were. All different colors and sizes. My daughter was a little freaked out at first with them flying so close..she's 16 lol, but once they started landing on her brothers she got jealous ha ha and didn't want to leave until she got one to come to her. There is also a huge coi pond to sit and look at as well as a small honey bee exhibit. All very cool. We spent well over an hour inside with the butterflies before we did have to step out to the cooler air , but more so because the kids were hungry. It was very expensive, but if you love to learn and try something most people do g get s chance to then it's worth it to me. My kids could not stop talking about it and were so happy. I'd say that's a day worth it all. Win win for mom since they learned some new things as well. I'd go back.

I've been here twice now and loved it both times! I saw some people skip the movie, but I would recommend watching it cuz you'll learn a lot about the Monarch Butterfly and the 3D is really cool! Wear bright colors to attract the butterflies, but it is a bit humid in the Butterfly area so dress accordingly. Then prepare yourself for a wonderful experience!

GO. Period - end of story. You just need to go.   Seriously, though - I have been to a number of butterfly atriums and this one was definitely my favorite. (we didn't do the maze thing next door, just the butterfly place). Very interesting film on the front end (SUPER interesting). The Atrium itself is the largest I've ever seen. The number of butterflies was almost overwhelming (it might be the time of year). There were a few times that you looked up and almost felt a bit of vertigo because so much was flying overhead.  Lots of different kinds, colors, sizes, shapes. You just can't go to a place like this and leave in a bad mood.  Stop what you're doing and add it to your to-do list now. You'll be glad you did. (ps - I read a couple of reviews about the room temperature... uh, it's kind of expected when you go to this kind of facility. I went 4th of July weekend, it was perfectly fine and what I expected)

Gosh... This place is great.  A butterfly conservatory where you can frolic amongst the butterflies.  ...But...before being turned loose in the atrium, you get to watch a short film.  At the beginning, it introduces a caterpillar that will become a butterfly. I became so choked up from trying to hold my laughter somewhere around this part...   "After the caterpillar hatches, it is very hungry and immediately snacks on it's shell casing..." It proceeds to show the caterpillar doing so while making slurpy eating sounds. Then I hear a lady scoff... "That's disgusting."  I barely held it together.  The atrium is awesome and fun. My friend and I stayed a pretty long while. A butterfly landed on my arm and stayed with me the entire time. I imagined that it would eventually flutter away naturally before the time came for us to leave. But not exactly, my friend's face suddenly turned flustered as he flash-backed to his "living in Florida days" do to the heat and humidity contained inside the atrium. He said "I can't take it anymore, we must leave now." I'm like... "But there is a butterfly resting on me." I insisted that I wanted her to naturally drift away! He eventually "naturally" made a puff of air with his mouth and blew it towards my arm. There is still an ongoing debate about the "naturalness" of this.   So...  If your timing is right you'll even get to see a butterfly hatch from a cocoon. You'll also learn how to tell male or female. You'll just learn A LOT of things. You'll really love it.

The butterfly habitat is very nice. It's basically a greenhouse with lots of butterflies flying around. Lovely if you like butterflies. I withheld a star because the reptile and fish exhibits you have to walk through after you leave the butterflies on the way out are really, really sad. The habitats are very small and filled with plastic plants. The animals seem very unhappy and looking for ways to escape. Some are alone, and none have room to have the exercise and adventure they would have in the wild. It was 2 days ago that I left and although I enjoyed the butterflies very much, I am still saddened every time I think of the other creatures in those small tanks.
Very nice place. The admission price is WAY TO EXPENSIVE for what they have to offer right now. I ONLY recommend it for butterfly lovers.

I just wanted to give a huge thank you to a wonderful woman named Dawn whom we encountered three times during our visit. The first, she engaged my two young daughters, let us take pictures with a butterfly that they were caring around with a sweet brush, and answered all of our questions. She was so sweet and kind to us. The second, she witnessed my daughter fall and hit her head. She waited and gave us an adequate amount of time to comfort her, and then approached us asking if she was alright and if she needed anything. She offered an ice pack, to go inside to cool off, a soda? Anything to make her feel better. She was very genuine and caring.  She even asked later if she was okay. The third time we left and realized we left a jacket. We came all the way back and asked the front desk if anyone had found one. They said no and that was that.  I decided to go in and look for myself, because I knew it had to be in there somewhere. Then we saw dawn walking by. I quickly asked her, she said no but didn't let it be that. She went above and beyond and offered to walk us around and ask lost and found, look in the theater, and the exhibit where we finally found it. She even gave me a hug! She was such a life saver today and was so appreciated. She's the definition of amazing customer service.

Most definitely a great experience if you have young ones. There is an educational video for all and a nice large atrium to actually interact with a plethora of butterflies. I would highly recommend this place for kiddos. However, being older now and actually have learned about butterflies at a younger age, this place is a "been there done that" type of experience for the adults.  This is a neat place to have in phx.

Took the family here and had a good experience overall. The butterfly exhibit was nice.  Been to something similar a few times, and it is definetly cool to see the variety of butterflies up close. The 3D butterfly movie was informative, and gave a nice overview of the life of the monarch butterfly. They did have a very small reptile section.  Nothing to get excited about,  but I was able to catch a Boa yawning, which was maybe my highlight of the visit. They also have a very small sea life section.  And that was about it. I wouldn't expect to spend too much time here. You can easily see everything in an hour or two.   They had a nice gift shop, and they had two penny machines for those that need to fill their penny passports.

So we checked out the Butterfly Wonderland today and I will say it is fairly cool and should be a nice addition to the many attractions in the greater Phoenix area for kids/families.   Cons - Price. Prices seem high. We actually ended up buying the lifetime membership (I know, I know, suckered into it! HA!), but considering our kids are small, it should easily pay for itself. But for a small family for the daily admission, it is easily $50, which to me seems like a lot. It is also EXTREMELY humid in the butterfly exhibit. I read other reviews saying it was humid, but dang, it is HUMID. Like so misty in there that you can't see across the entire exhibit since it is so foggy. This isn't necessarily a con or a bad thing, just be prepared. Don't bother showering or doing your hair. ;)   Pros - The 15 min long 3D butterfly movie is fairly cool. Fun to watch the smaller kids all reaching out to "touch" the butterflies during the movie. They also have a room with various stages of cocoons and you can even watch butterflies emerge if you are patient enough. The butterfly room, although humid, is very beautiful. The exhibit will be better as the plants grow in, but overall pretty well done already. The volunteers/people answering questions in the exhibits were friendly and helpful. They also have a small room with some ants, scorpions and bee exhibits. Interesting, but nothing nearly as exciting as the butterflies. They also have room with various fish tanks and an open tank for petting/touching sting rays.  There is definitely some newness/growing pains since they recently opened, but I think once this is worked through, it will be well worth everyone to at least check it out once. We were there about 2 1/2 hours and it was definitely a nice relief from the 110 degree heat outside (even with the humidity!)

Really unique experience. A little pricey for what it offers, but it can't be cheap to operate, so I can understand. With such few fun summertime options for the kids, I'm happy to have it in the neighborhood.

Talk about amazing. The Butterflies are beyond words... So beautiful. Wear bright colors for sure. We also did the maze which was short but fun. The movie you watch prior to going into the exhibit was interesting... It is not something I would go over and over again but i definitely enjoyed it.

I went on September 1st and I have to say I was miserable.  It was over 65.00 for two adults and a 5yr and 8yr old.  We waited in a long line front from the begining and then went to see a movie.  The movie was good and we did like that but everything else was poor.  This place is beautiful on the outside but a poor set up on the inside.  Hot and humid and the butterfly exhibit though beautiful had dead ends in each section, It would of been more functional to keep it going with the walk way so it was not so congested. Also the ant exhibit was horrible and the fish tanks were really no big deal.  We live in Arizona so we know what scorpions are.  Just think the fee to get in was way to much for what you were given.  The cafeteria cost 13.00 for two bags of candy and two juice boxes and then you leave thru the gift store which every kid was complaining as they wanted a toy or somthing.  Clever on the store part but not fair to the parents.  We bought a plastic butterfly ring and with tax as 4.91 for a 10 cent ring. I will never go back and I bet this will be closed down before to long.   Sorry but have to be honest.
it was amazing, I loved the manta rays and the butterflies were really cool. they plan on expanding it soon. There were a lot of helpful volunteer and spiders and snakes and other reptiles as well.

Butterfly Wonderland just opened up May 25th, and there were a lot of families and couples lined up to experience America's newest and largest butterfly conservatory.   Admission is about $19 for each adult, with senior and student discounts. When you enter, you have the choice of seeing the 3D movie or moving onward to the next room. The movie is around 15 minutes, and shows off the 3D views and pretty imagery rather than a lot of informative discussion about the monarch butterfly.  After the movie, you enter a room that showcases the different pupae that are in the process of transforming into a butterfly. Since there was a large crowd when we went, there was a little bit of a wait for patrons in the actual conservatory to exit before more could enter.  The actual conservatory is a photography student's dream. The landscape is a bit ethereal as various butterflies flutter by you. Some may even land on you for a quick second before taking off again. Although we did have a guide to the different species of butterflies in our brochure, there wasn't much else in terms of education about the different butterflies.  The next section after the conservatory shows a honeybee colony and several ant colonies. The ant colonies in agar were lighted up with neon, making it look like the ants were having a rave. It was cool to see the honeybees, with the queen marked with a green dot to differentiate her from the other bees.  There is also a set of nice aquariums, and a touch pool with stingrays. The aquarium was a weird addition to a butterfly conservatory I thought. The fish were all freshwater common species you could find at your nearest Petsmart (e.g., African cichlids, various gourami, neon tetras). There were a few signs listing the species, but not all the aquariums were labeled. Like the butterfly section, the stingray and fish section didn't have a lot of educational information in them.   It took us about an hour to browse through everything. The experience here is nice, but it's more of a visual experience rather than a learning one. Some things that might be good for the exhibits are more information about butterfly conservation, why the different species of butterflies are differently colored, and how different cultures view butterflies. Since there are so many children that visit the conservatory, it would be nice for them to be enticed to learn about nature in addition to the visual interactive beauty of the butterflies.

This place is fun for the kids and adults. The 3d imax like movie was fun. Watching the Butterflies flitter about in the atrium was also fun, but be prepared for the humidity. Overall worth the money and a fun experience.  They will be building an aquarium in about a year so it will be a more robust experience.

Very cool place. The 3D video in the beginning is great! But, of course, the atrium is where it's at. Really could spend forever just looking at the butterflies and it's a photographers dream. Gave it 3 stars because it seems over pretty quickly for the price. Might as well make more a day of it and go to Odysea next door too. They have a deal for both tickets.

Butterfly Wonderland was so amazing to walk through!  I was worried my young son would try and grab a butterfly or we might accidentally step on one but NOPE! it was nice and humid and the butterflies were just batting around us, how magical is that? It's a fairly fast process and unless your older and want to admire all around.  The tickets were a little steep especially for the amount of time we actually stayed in the actual Wonderland but it would be easy to stay longer if the children were again, older.  I will be back soon and suggest you try out butterfly Wonderland for yourself!

So fun!! We love BFW. My kids school does field trips here every year. The IMAX video is awesome & so informative!!! And we love the butterflies and the other critters. But go with water and a snack because the butterfly exhibit is very humid and hot. Kids seem to get hungry!! Make sure to wear bright colors if you want to better place to land on you, they seem to like the color orange. A boy in my group had a butterfly laying eggs on his golden hair today!!

This place was great for our 2 year old. There is a movie at the beginning that I highly recommend you watch! The actual butterfly exhibit is a lot smaller that what I was expecting and I imagine it gets really crowded. We went on Sunday morning right when it opened and there were very few people which was nice! Overall we really liked it!
Great place to visit! We really enjoyed the time we spent here.

If you love butterflies, then this is a must while your in Arizona. You start off watching a great 3d movie that explains the life of a monarch butterfly. After you exit the movie you can watch for hatching butterflies or walk into the Butterfly Wonderland.

I didn't know what to expect, except to duck in out of the last August heat. The movie was educational and not at all boring. The staff was very generous with their time and expertise. The butterfly room was stunningly beautiful and peaceful. I had never seen anything like it. We stayed for a long while because we were charmed at every turn. We ranged from 6-65 in age and became even more devoted to the preservation of wildlife. Can't wait to go back to see the new aquarium adjacent.

Overall a great and fun experience.    Came here with my little pumpkin to explore and try something new.  I recommend arriving when the opens as it wasn't busy at all and had ample space to enjoy ourselves.   Butterflies galore. I did not expect so many and so many varieties. You literally walk around and they are flying everywhere landing where they please.  They have a pleasant Koi pond right in the middle where you can enjoy a seat next to these beautiful fish. It is a bit humid in there as they regulate the temps for the butterflies so dress accordingly.   Once you've had your fill make your way through the cafe to a small portion or the aquarium that is open. Just a few fish tanks with fresh water fish and a sting ray pen where you can touch them ( wash your hands prior ) they have a sink nearby.   Had a great time. Only downside is it is pricey for what you get.  Sort of seen it once I'm good not sure I'd be back unless there was a major attraction change.

One of the coolest things to do in Phoenix area. A bit pricey but it's a neat experience for both adults and kids. Didn't know so many kinds of butterflies existed and its fun seeing them fly around in the open.   My only complaint is that the woman who was working the front to take the tickets was rude and had a stank attitude when we didn't know we had to get the tickets in the gift shop. It was a weekday and it was slow. We were excited to be there...she could at least crack a smile.
This place is fantastic! We definitely recommend going! We loved having the butterflies all around us!

This is a magnificent treat to visit if you're in the Scottsdale area. There's a fantastic educational 3D movie, helpful labels and staff that are knowledgeable and pleasant too. The butterfly enclosure had a wonderful variety of butterflies to observe. And the hatching area was also interesting to see. There are some gratuitous fish and desert insect displays (in other words, not very extensive - but still cool to see) besides the butterflies. I didn't try the cafe, but there is one if you get hungry. The gift shop offers a wide variety of on-theme merch at different price points. And, you can spend a fortune buying the requisite tourist-spot (e.g, large markup) shot of yourself in front of a green screen (that allows the Wonderland folks to Photoshop your image into a rainforest backdrop with butterflies thrown in for color). Perhaps because I know that memory card images are free and sheets of printer paper cost $1-2 max for the quality used, the price seemed high. But if the remembrance is worth it to you, it's a cute memento... Be aware the entry price to the Wonderland is also high. I'm assuming they're plowing the majority of their funds into the ongoing construction of the SeaWorld-like place that's going in next door. Check the Wonderland out. It's worth a visit to see those terrific butterflies.

This place was a total surprise for me.  I was not expecting much but really enjoyed the whole experience.  The 3-d movie was fantastic and one of the best films made in 3-d I have ever seen.  It was very serene to be in the butterfly garden and to see so many of them fluttering about.  The aquariums and sting ray touch tank was a bonus!

Who doesn't like and admire butterflies?  If you don't, then you are missing out. These little creatures transform from a mass that barely moves into a colorful, graceful,  delicate little air dancing machine.  The Butterfly Wonderland has the largest atrium in the US for butterflies to roam around.  It's quite an amazing site watching these amazing little spectacles fly around near plants that grow well here in AZ. So if you're a plant lover then this place will be of interest to you as well.  Upon arrival here, some may be shocked with the admission price of $18.95 for adults and $10 for kids. If you're budget friendly this is not the place for you.  I feel that this place is definitely worth it to check out, but with the lofty admission I could see guests only coming back every so many years and not becoming regulars.  Overall the place is not huge so give yourself about an hour and a half to enjoy everything. Make sure to not skip the 3D Monarch butterfly show as you start your journey.

The movie was very informative and it's pretty seeing the butterfly exhibit. The staff is accommodating and friendly. I have been to several other butterfly exhibits outside of AZ and they are usually not stand alone but connected to other exhibits so that's why I rated it down. I'm not sure that it's worth visiting more than once or the price of the exhibit is worth it. I love butterflies so I would have gone regardless.

Wow! This museum is truly amazing and fun for all ages. The greenhouse where the butterflies are kept is a true wonderland, even though it is especially hot and humid. Bring an extra shirt to change into. ;) the variety of fluttering butterflies is amazing. They alight on you if you stand still long enough. It is fun to observe others who have no idea they have butterflies on their back.   We brought our toddlers and they loved the pond, waterfall and larger butterflies   as they toddler around.  A definite fun experience for 1.5-2 hours. The aquarium and reptile areas were fun as well! They feed the fish at about 11 AM, which makes it fun to watch.  Enjoy!
A tad bit overpriced, but the kids loved it. Very educational experience for kids and adults. The movie was in 3D and a great part of the experience.

To be completely honest, I was coerced into coming to this place. It wasn't one of the must-see places for me while visiting Phoenix however I actually really enjoyed myself here. If I were to sum up my experience in one word, I would probably say it was "unique".   I enjoyed learning about butterflies and how they migrate. The film you watch before entering the butterfly forest was very educational. The actual butterfly museum was very nice. I will warn you that it is very humid and misty. I would also recommend that you wear bright colors. This attracts the butterflies to you.   This place is fun for all ages but for me was a little on the expensive side ($19 per adult). I would definitely recommend bringing kids here. The kids seem to love this place. Overall, I had an enjoyable time.

Wish I could give this a 3.5.  Very cool to check out, but not something I'd do very often as it's pricey. Many places around Phoenix have very good membership deals like the Botanical Gardens (who also have a smaller butterfly exhibit annually) or the Natural History Museum. I probably would have bought a membership if it was reasonable (there are no memberships for couples without children, so it'd be $100 a year for just two), but you'd have to really go a lot to get your money's worth.   Also, if you're looking for a relaxing butterfly experience, this isn't it. I'd recommend checking out t he Botanical Gardens to see if they're doing their butterfly exhibit. It's much calmer. Beware: going during the middle of the week does not mean less kids, they are a hotspot for class field trips, and the ratio of adults-to-children may actually be lower midweek than on the weekends.  If you're good with crowds, Butterfly Wonderland has a great 3D film that I haven't seen anything like other places.   Also: I recommend dressing in layers! The theater is a bit chilly but the butterfly pavilion is quite muggy. A tank top + sweatshirt is perfect.

I went here a few years ago and didn't know what to expect. I was not disappointed. They had this cool documentary about monarch butterflies and how they migrate from a forest in Mexico all the way to Canada through Texas and back to Mexico. This takes multiple generations of butterflies. They eat milkweed. Since my sister lives in Texas I told her about it and she and her kids ended up planting milkweeds in her garden for them. You then go into this sealed room where there are a ton of butterflies. It's so cool. They come and land on your clothes. They are all different colors. I definitely recommend this place. Very kid friendly

This place is fantastic.  I can understand why some people may think it's pricey, but you're paying for such a unique experience that I believe it to be completely worth it.  We had a large group of all ages including some of my family in town from the Northeast, and everyone had a fantastic and memorable time.  Perfect spot for kids of all ages!

This is unique, fun, and a great way to be a kid again! It is a little pricey but I thought it was worth it and would do it again. The video is educational and really makes you appreciate what it takes in nature for all these amazing species to survive. The room with the cocoons is really neat and you actually see some emerging at times. The actual butterfly pavilion is amazing. So many beautiful butterflies and they land right on you and it is peaceful and amazing. Then they have a small exhibit with bees and ants and scorpions etc. They do try to sell you a picture but ours came out really great so we got it as a fun souvenir. I would go back maybe once every six months as something fun and different to do!

We got a 10 percent discount from the hotel we were staying so well worth the price.  The 3-D movie was only about 15 minutes, but it was cool.  And the butterflies were gorgeous.  Next you go into a room where you can see butterfly chrysallis and they're actually hatching out of them right then and there.  If you have the patience, you can see several different types of butterfly emerging.  Next area is where all the butterfly are.  There are a ton.  Way more than you'd see at the butterfly attraction in San Diego.  The minute you walk in, there are a swarm of butterflies.  You have to watch where you place your feet as well, as there are butterflies on the ground as well.    Several butterflies landed on my daughter.  She was both thrilled and nervous.  She wanted them to land on her, but it scared her a little.  At one point, I had three butterflies landing on my shirt.    This is a great place for photographers.  You'll get a ton of butterfly photographs and there's so many different varieties.  The only drawback is that it is quite humid and hot.  My husband turned bright red, so we had to take a break in their snack room.   There's plenty of parking.  It's going to be part of the Odyssea complex some day.  It looks awesome.  I can't wait to go back when everything is in place.

I didn't really set any expectations for this place because I have never been to anything like this.  It was a fun experience.  The 3D movie at the beginning was really interesting.  The atrium was very humid, there are butterflies EVERYWHERE! I felt a bit intimidated as I was in their environment.  I was wary when walking because many of them land on the floor.  It's quite difficult to capture them as they fly around.. resulting in photos of flying black dots.  Its a great place to take kids.  As for the pricey entrance.. we would not come back unless we someone out of state were to visit.

Went here on an adult field trip with my girlfriend. It was a great date activity. It's a little hot to be going here in the Summer, and it's definitely humid inside with the butterflies, but it's worth going for sure.   We went ahead and bought annual passes because that's like our thing now - annual passes for shit we'll end up going to just once or twice. We were bummed to find out we had just missed the lifetime passes - they stopped selling them.   But there's a ton of cool stuff to see here besides just butterflies, and the 3d movie was entertaining. We got our money out of it. The photography opportunities here are fantastic. I brought my dslr and snapped off a bunch. If you're into photography at all, this is a great place to go as well. The atrium is well laid out and there's even a nice koi pond in the middle... we probably wandered around for a good hour and a half or so.   Watch your step - you may squish one. They are pretty good about cleaning up the casualties and they are also good about warning visitors not to be dicks - but people are dicks so you may see some trampled on butterflies. Just be aware.  If you're a parent and bringing your children here and they don't understand death yet and will cry when they see a dead butterfly and you aren't ready to have that talk... or they misbehave and pull wings off or kill insects because you are raising a serial murderer - then this probably isn't the place for you. Take your kid to the playground at McDonalds and feed them a happy meal. This is a more sophisticated outing for a more sophisticated child and parent. It's an educational thing and also might spark a love for butterflies.   Dudebros - this is a great place to take a chick on a date - but maybe not in the Summer - her makeup will sweat off her face and her hair will frizz out. If she's cool with that, then you've got yourself a good one. If you're not cool with that as a dudebro, then maybe you are shallow and should talk to someone about it... I don't know.   The giftshop is neat and filled with some good stuff, but it's all very expensive. Overall, it's a great experience that doesn't cost much more than going to the movies and provides a much more unique experience.

For being the biggest butterfly exhibit in the US it is not that big... I had a great time nonetheless :) once you walk in you watch an informative 3D movie about the monarch butterfly.
